text:
This pie is the BEST!!  So easy too!  Just a few notes:  

3/4 cup Key Lime juice is = to about 20 Key limes.  I used a garlic press to squeeze the limes quickly and easily (cut limes in half).  

3 Cups of sweetened condensed milk = about 2 cans.  

Perfect recipe!  Impress your friends and enjoy!

text:
I love this recipe. I am from Florida and have had many key lime pies when visiting key west. This is the most authentic tasting pie I have ever made at home. What is best is that it is SO SIMPLE! You can literally whip it up in no time. I used home made whipped topping (heavy whipping cream with a touch of sugar and vanilla) and spread it over the entire pie. I made this for my husbands birthday dinner party. I have since made this pie 3 more times. Everytime we are invited to dinner friends ask me to make this pie for them, it is PERFECT! Do not try another key lime pie recipe on this site, this is the only one you need!

text:
This recipe was my second choice, but should have been my first!!  I made two pies for Easter from a different recipe that called for eggs, and we hated them!  They were dense and heavy, more like a custard than anything, with a bitter lime taste. Then I went in search of a lighter recipe, one without the eggs. This was the recipe I was looking for!! Light, creamy, not too tart or too sweet! PERFECT! I didn't stick with the key limes, (I found the key lime juice to be terribly acidic when I used it in the first recipe) instead I used about 8 Mexican limes that I found in my grocery produce section. They're a little smaller than the traditional Perisian limes, but a bit bigger than the Key Limes. They worked wonderfully! I ended up with 2 cups of juice and used it all for two pies. I used 4 cans of condensed milk, and baked for closer to 13 minutes in shortbread crusts. Topped with homemade whipped cream and YUMMO! Everyone freaked over this pie! I will use this recipe forever! Thanks so much for sharing it!

text:
This was really easy. I used Mothers Oatmeal Cookies as a crust instead of a graham cracker crust. Everything else I kept the same. Really took a matter of minutes, longest part was breaking up the cookies in the blender. I also used Rose's Key Lime juice. EDITED: I liked the combination of the oatmeal cookie crust with the pie filling, I just found the pie a little sweet. I think if I make a key lime pie again, I'll look for one that's creamier and less sweet. EDITED AGAIN: This was even better the next day. I LOVED this pie. EDITED AGAIN: I have doubled the recipe for this and used a homemade graham crust or a pretzel crust and it's always turned out fantastic. This dessert is always a homerun, I've never had leftovers when I make this pie for a gathering or potluck.

text:
I sat here forever trying to decide which Key Lime Pie to make and finally chose this one and I'm glad I did!  It's so creamy and has the perfect amount of lime and it held together perfectly!  I only added 1 t grated peel, my 35 little limes only made a little less than 3/4 C (boy are my thumbs sore from squeezing those things!), didn't measure the milk, just used 2 cans as others suggested and used reduced fat sour cream.  I made it with the Graham Cracker Crust II from this site since it didn't call for sugar.  I didn't get the bubbles like so many others so I just baked it for 10 minutes.

I think this is a 10 star recipe! It makes a beautiful pie, so simple to make, and absolutely delicious. I made two Key Lime pies, one with egg whites folded in and this recipe. This one stole the show. It was prettier and creamier. I added about 1 1/2 ounce of lime jello for color and flavor but I heard that a true key lime does not have green coloring. I found the key lime juice in the juice section at one grocery store and the liquor section at another. I cannot imagine someone squeezing 20 key limes! I think I baked it for 15 minutes - those pin holes were hard to detect!

Display Name:
ellie may

country:
None
text:
Incredible pie, easy, affordable and tasty! I skipped the lime zest; not needed at all as I prefer a smooth and creamy texture and it already has a lot of "limey" flavor! It took 15 Key Limes, they were 10 for 1.00US here. If you use the larger Persian limes or Mexican limes, you would need much less (3-5 limes) to make 3/4 cup of juice, so do not let the cost of the limes stop you from making this sublime recipe. I often make my own graham cracker crust, but this time I used a Keebler pre-made that states you get "two extra servings" and the total amount of filling was PERFECT for that size. I used two cans of sweetened condensed milk (28 oz. total), rather than 3 cups (24 oz.). I baked it in a pre-heated oven for 10 minutes; there was just a few pinhole sized bubbles under the smooth top layer that did not burst. The pie was set nicely, however, so no worries. Turned the oven off; let it sit there for 1/2 hour and then put it in the frig overnight. Served with cream, whipped with vanilla & confectioners sugar. Total cost was just over $10.00. Worth every penny. This would be a great dessert to take somewhere, it seems foolproof and it was my first time to make it. I would highly recommend even if you think you don't like lime or don't usually make pie. Doesn't heat up the kitchen with that short bake time. Turn the oven on after the limes are juiced, especially if you use a garlic press. It takes just a minute to stir and fold into the crust. Pure yum!

text:
I absolutely love Key Lime pie! This recipe was a fabulous starting point in which I experimented incorporating various suggestions I discovered here to where I believe I've refined it to perfection! Try this: 1 can (14oz) of condensed milk; 8 oz whipped cream cheese (make sure it's of the whipped variety); 1/2 cup (4oz) sour cream; 3/4 cup key lime juice; 1 tablespoon of grated lime zest (definitely makes a difference by adding zing to the flavor); 1 (9 inch) prepared graham cracker crust; 8 oz cool whip.
Preheat oven to 375 degrees farenheit. The substitution of the whipped cream cheese not only greatly improves the flavor but also cuts back on the calaries! You can cut down further using the low fat/lite versions of all the ingredients.  Just put the milk, cream cheese, sour cream and key lime juice into a blender and blend it up. Then add the grated lime zest and stir it around before pouring the mixture into the graham cracker crust. If you're making your own crust I recommend using coconut oil instead of butter. It's MUCH healthier! Use a food processor to crush up the graham crackers or if you don't have one use a ziplock to smash them all up, then place in 9 inch pan, pour just enough oil or butter to allow crumbs to gel while pressing throughout with large spoon. Bake 15 minutes. After cooling in refrigerator for half an hour spread cool whip across the top like you're spreading frosting on a cake. Try this variation and I promise you won't be disappointed!

text:
Pretty good.  Not too sweet, not too tart and I liked that it required no eggs.  I do wonder about the amount of condensed milk it calls for though.  I suppose you could make your own condensed milk, but I think most people use the canned variety.  Two 14 oz. cans are not quite three cups, but result in the perfect amount of filling.  Take the extra time to make a homemade graham crust by mixing 1/3c sugar, 6T. melted butter and about ten sheets of crushed graham crackers (or 1.5 c. of crumbs) and press into pie plate.  Bake for 5 minutes at 325, let cool a little, add filling and bake as the recipe states.  It ended up taking 11 minutes for the pie to be fully cooked.  Perfect with a bit of homemade whipped cream on top.

text:
fantastic recipe!   I have made this pie many times now, every time is a success.  The texture is very light and airy (as key lime pies go), and never overly rich or custard like.  It's exactly what a key lime pie should be, which is to say, something different than a custard pie.  The lime juice actually reacts with the dairy ingredients to thicken the pie, so it lacks any eggy taste or texture.  I never have key lime juice when I make it, so I always substitute the juice of three or four mexican limes, and about a 1/3 cup lemon juice.  It's still loaded with key lime pie flavor!  Really perfect recipe.  Three cups condensed milk is essentially two cans and a half cup sour cream is half a small container, for anyone confused.  A note on the cooking,  I normally take it out after 10-12 min, because I've found that it sets a little better that way.   It pairs really well with a slightly brown sugared graham cracker crust and fresh whipped cream!

text:
TARTY AND EASY! I was a little suspicious that such a simple recipe could be any good, but this is a very good pie. I used bottled key lime juice to save time, but I made my own graham cracker crust and the finished pie was chilling in about 40 minutes. A little whip cream compliments and cuts the tartness of the lime. Don't neglect the lime zest! Those little green bits floating in the filling are what separates the store bought from the homemade.

text:
THE BEST!! Not to tart, and not to sweet. Made for a small gathering of mostly native So. Floridians who have eaten numerous key lime pies over the years. Everyone said this was the best key lime pie they have had, and demanded the recipe. Also used Graham Cracker Crust I and Whipped Cream recipes from this site to make the pie. From reading reviews, some folks don’t seem to know that key limes are quite small (rough size of a quarter) and more tart than the common Persian lime (more pie photos show Persian rather than key limes). Key limes are a/k/a Bartender’s limes; a liquor store may have them if not found at your grocery store. For a bit of trivia, the key lime was predominate in the US until the 1926 hurricane wiped out the Florida Keys and its lime crops. If fresh key limes are not available, the suggestion by others to use Nellie & Joe's Famous Key West Lime Juice is a good one if wanting to make an authentic key lime pie (sold by Whole Foods in S. Florida). My 1 lb. bag ($3.99) had 21 key limes, and made 5/8 cup of juice. A second bag was used to get a full 3/4 cup, and to cut slices for garnish w/ remainder to be used in other dishes. I baked my pie for 11 minutes per suggestion of other reviewers (tiny bubbles were barely detectable when they do appear), and I let it rest for 24 hrs. before serving. Thanks a bunch to Ann Richardson for sharing this wonderful recipe!

text:
WOW!  This was AMAZING! I had never had Key Lime pie before so I had nothing to compare it to but I will never try another recipe for one again because I don't think it could get any better than this and it was so incredibly easy to make! I served it to 5 adults and we all LOVED it!  I used Nellie and Joe's Key Lime juice because there were no key limes to be found and I skipped the lime zest because my husband and I don't like the bitterness it has. I used 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk.  I made the graham cracker crust from scratch which was 1 pkg. graham crackers, 6 tbs. butter and 1/4 cup sugar.  I cooked the crust for 5 min, put the filling in and cooked it for 8 min. I didn't get the tiny bubbles on top until I took it out of the oven.  The pie was very creamy and held together well. I topped it with homemade whipped cream which was 2 cups whipping cream whipped until soft peaks formed, then add 2 tsp. vanilla and 6 tbs. powdered sugar and whipped until ready.  I will be making this again and again!

text:
This was the best and easiest homemade Key Lime Pie, I've ever made!  I recently used this recipe at out annual holiday party and everyone raved about it!  The filling has a very subtle sweet-tart balance, not too overpowering in either direction.  I used 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk, which was almost equal to three cups, and it seemed to be the perfect amount for a normal pie crust, but not nearly enough for a deep dish one - in case anyone was wondering.  I skipped the lime zest entirely, as I was using canned lime juice and didn't have any fresh lime on hand, though I'd imagine that adding the lime zest would definitely give this pie a little bit more of a lime kick.  I topped this with a homemade whipped topping, and it was amazing!  Some reviewers had mentioned that they were unable to see the bubbles on the surface of the pie, I could see them however, in a very well lit kitchen though - so look very closely.  10 minutes tops, no more is needed.  I made this pie two days before it was needed, and it held up well in the fridge.  Thank you for a quick and easy key lime pie recipe!  This is for sure a keeper!

text:
I just made it again, this time I used Plain, Non-fat Greek yogurt (Chobani) and it is probably the best yet!   The non-fat sweetened condense milk version was indistinguishable from regular so this could be a fabulous non-fat dessert for those wanting to reduce the fat in the diet.

I have made this recipe many times.  I just took another one out of the oven.  It is great.  Cannot detect a difference between regular and low fat sour cream so I used the reduced fat version.  The one I just made is my first experiment with fat free sw. condensed milk.

I like to make it in an 8 inch tart pan which needs just 1/2 cup of juice, 1 can of sw. cond. milk, 1/3 cup sour cream.  I always bake it for 15 minutes and just get the tiny bubbles starting to form.  I can't imagine only baking the full size version for 5 to 8 minutes.   I suspect that's what caused the problems for the reviewer that didn't like it and said it formed brown liquid the next day.

Who has this pie left the next day?

OH MY GOSH - there is a reason this is a 5-star recipe with over 1,360+ reviews.  Add my 5-stars to that total.  This recipe was HIGHLY recommended to me from the morning gals on thebuzz. country:
None
text:
Excellent pie & super easy recipe!  We're from FL and are very picky about our Key Lime Pie.  I can't tell you how many variations I've tried over the years, and we liked this the best.  As with any recipe - TASTE AS YOU'RE MAKING AND ADJUST.  If you like the filling as is, then you're done.  If you're not happy, fix it.  We like ours on the tart side, so I used about 4/5 cup of fresh lime juice, 1 1/2 Tbs. grated lime zest and 1 cup of sour cream, along with 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk so it wouldn't be too thin.  Juicing hint: if your key limes are hard, microwave them for about 10 seconds, then roll on the counter with the palm of your hand to loosen the juice (zest first).  If your limes aren't yellow, they might be too young - let them ripen on the counter a few days.  Paired this filling with Janaan Cunningham's excellent graham cracker crust recipe.  For planning purposes, pie takes about 4 hours to chill right out of the oven & into the fridge.  I was afraid it would be too thin with the extra juice, but the extra sour cream did the trick & after baking it was perfect.  Some folks like to add cream cheese instead of sour cream - still tasty, but it does change the consistency.

city:

country:
None
text:
This key lime pie was better than the one we had in Florida!  I used 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk, Nellie & Joe's key lime juice and omitted the grated lime peel.  I made a shortbread crust and homemade whipped topping.  Crust: 24 Lorna Doonie cookies (crushed), 1 T sugar and 1/4 cup melted BUTTER.  Mix together and pat down & up sides of a (slightly greased) 9-inch pie plate.  Bake 325' for 10 minutes.  Cool completely!  Homemade whipped topping:  Beat 1 cup heavy whipping cream until soft peaks form.  Add 1/4 cup powdered sugar and 1/4 t vanilla.  Beat until stiff.  Spread over entire pie.  If you love key lime pie, this is the recipe for you!!  You will NOT be disappointed!! Very easy and absolutely delicious!  Truly a keeper!  (Another suggestion is to drizzle a homemade raspberry sauce on the bottom of the plate before serving. :)

text:
This pie is amazing!! I was very skeptical as I  couldn't imagine an authentic key lime pie made with sour cream and no egg yolks. I was wrong. This pie is just as delicious, if not more so, than the traditional recipe. The sour cream makes it a creamier, denser pie without compromising the authentic key lime flavor. My husband and sons, who consider themselves to be true key lime pie afficionados, now prefer this recipe over the traditional one. As others have recommended, I used 2 (14 oz.) cans of condensed milk. I also used Nellie and Joe's key lime juice. For the crust, I used the Graham Cracker Crust I recipe from this site with a few changes to the crust mixture - added 1/2 tsp. cinnamon and only 1/4 cup sugar. To any skeptics, TRY THIS PIE!

text:
delicious. Use 2 cans sweetened condensed milk instead (read reviews) instead of measuring 3 cups. I used light sour cream, 1 cup key lime juice (makes it more tart), no lime zest, and a couple drops of green food coloring. Otherwise it's just as written and it's delicious!!  You MUST use key lime juice NOT lime juice.  It makes more than one pie if you use the little metal pans and make your own crust. When I doubled it, it made two pie pans and one 8x8 pan. 

I had to cook it longer (homemade thicker crust I think), but do NOT let it brown.  When the edges start to look shiny and it has thickened some that's when it's done.  It will thicken after it's chilled.  I never had the bubbles pop on the top (the recipe says to look for bubbles), so I just watched it like a hawk.

text:
So very delicious and super easy! I didn't change a single thing and it turned out scrumptious! One thing though, I see lots of reviews stating "two cans of sweetened condensed milk was plenty, wouldn't use three". This is reader error. If you look at the recipe, it calls for 3 CUPS not three cans. And... you are supposed to achieve this by opening up two cans and measuring out 3 cups worth. But really, just use the whole two cans. It will work out perfectly, I promise! :-)

text:
Hands down best key lime pie recipe ever! I've also used fat free sweetened cond. milk.  You can also make into mini key lime pies using cupcake pans lined with paper cups and homemade graham cracker crust. Make your own crust using 1 sleeve graham crackers, 1/2 cup macadamia nuts, 2 tbsp brown sugar & 4 tbsp melted butter pulsed together in food processor. Pack 1 tbsp into the bottom of each cup, pour 1/4 cup batter on top and bake as directed. Top with a dollop of whipped cream and twist of lime.  You will not regret it!!!

text:
In college I worked in a restaurant that won awards every year for their Keylime Pie.  I knew they used sweetened condensed milk, sour cream and whipping cream - so I thought this came close enough and gave it a try. I only had 2 cups of Sweet Co. Milk, so I did use 1/2 cup of cream to substitute.  I used a home-made graham cracker crust - and home made whipped cream(for a topper).  The rest I did just as is....HOLY COW.  This was beyond delicious!  And it tasted JUST like that award winning pie - only the zest added a little extra goodness.  Thanks!

Fizz

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made 2 of these for Thanksgiving for something new any they were great.  Note that a 14oz can of Eagle Brand Sweetened Condensed Milk is exactly  1 cup so if you're using 14oz cans like me it takes 3 of them.  I will say though, all the ingredients together will overflow a standard 9" crust so you have to keep it thick so it can bulge up in the middle.  Otherwise go with the slightly larger crust or waste a bit.  I managed to get it to fit, but it got messy when I tried to reseal it in the plastic cover after cooling for transport; otherwise it'd be perfect.  I'll also warn you that if you zest the lime with an actual zester (where you get longer strips of the zest) it will not break down at all when you cook it and you'll have strands of lime zest in your pie.  Next time I will either try a grater to zest, or I'll chop it up.  And finally, I never saw a single pinhole bubble burst by 10 minutes so I pulled it out.  It was still fine....not browned and set perfectly.

Lee

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great. I have been making it for a couple years now and will never use another Key Lime Pie recipe. After reading a lot of other comments on here, I don't understand why it's taking 20+ key limes or so for others to extract 3/4 cup worth of juice. It only takes me 6-8 key limes, cut in half and squeezed by hand, to get 3/4 cup. The key is to buy the dark green key limes and check to make sure they're somewhat soft when squeezing. It will not hinder the flavor.

I also supplement the Graham Cracker crust with my own recipe using Keebler Shortbread Cookies. You will never go back after using this crust recipe. 1 (11.2 oz package) Keebler Sandies Shortbread Cookies, 4 tbsp Butter Flavored Crisco, 4 tbsp sugar. Crush the cookies into a powder using a processor, mix with the sugar and Crisco, and pack it nicely into your pie dish. Bake @ 325 degrees for about 10 minutes before adding the pie filling (then bake again according to this recipe's instructions). It tastes great.

text:
I made this with one can of fat free sweetened condensed milk and one regular, because I had these in my pantry needing to be used up, and used Daisy light sour cream. I accidentally put in too much sour cream, thinking it said one cup. I tried to remove some of it but probably ended up with 3/4 cup or more of sour cream. My mistake turned out to make one of the best Key Lime pies I've ever tasted. Usually they are too tart or too sweet for me. I served this at a party of 14 people and even one person that hates sour cream loved it, and one that never likes Key lime loved it. You can't taste the sour cream in the pie, even with my extra. Every one said this was the best Key lime they ever had.  I did top with light dairy whip cream. I used the larger prepared pie crust that gives two extra servings. Honestly I don't think I've ever made a dessert that got so many raves and request for the recipe. The best part is I hate to bake and this was the easiest dessert I've ever made. Like another reviewer said, about ten minutes to prepare.

text:
Very good. The lime zest is super important. It is what gives the pie it's greenish color (not to mention added flavor). If you can't find fresh key limes, please don't use the bottled stuff. No matter what kind of citrus it is, the flavor diminishes soon after being squeezed and can turn harsh. In that case use regular limes. You can add lemon to them if you want.

text:
Delicious! I used 1lb key limes, 2 300mL cans of sweetened condensed milk, and light sour cream. It was perfect! If I had used a third can of condensed milk there would have been far too much filling (I had a bit extra with two). EDIT: I've made this pie a few times now, and still love it! My manfriend thought that it was a bit too sweet, so I made a slight adjustment this last time. I used 2 cups of sweetened condensed milk and 1 cup of plain greek yogurt, and left everything else the same. We reached our perfect level of sweet :) There was some extra filling, so I put it into a ramekin and baked that along with the pie. Note: I've made this pie both with and without the zest, and the flavour is excellent either way. I prefer to add the zest for the aesthetics :)

text:
This is By Far The BEST Key Lime I have had since my last couple trips to Florida. I used a whole bag of Key Limes, I cut them into quarters and pressed them in a garlic press something I learned about while reading a cooking magazine. I used 2 full 14 oz cans of sweetened condensed milk. Making a home baked graham cracker crust is fast, easy and makes a world of difference too. Garnishing is simple using a star tip pipping and fresh whipped cream with just a bit of powder sugar to stiffen it up. Adding a single slice of key lime to each piece of pie just before serving gives a gourmet look! This pie is so fast but guests will think you spent hours on it;)

text:
I found this recipe to be a fabulous choice if you want a creamy key lime pie. I used a store-bought graham cracker crust. It only took 7 limes for me to make a 3/4 cup. I used a garlic press to juice the limes, cutting them into 8ths and then squeezing the juice out. I strained off the pulp. It had a great kick to it! I also used 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk. I will definitely be making this pie again. My husband LOVED it!

asonetuh

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2171258.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, but for me it was way too sweet. 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk must have the equivalent of 10 cups of sugar in it! I experimented with two ways to cut the sweetness out, reducing the sweetened condensed milk to 1.5 cans instead of 2. In one I substituted sour cream, and the other I substituted evaporated milk (in a 1:1 volume ratio). I preferred the flavor of the pie with the evap milk substitution. Although it made it a little looser, it was still firm enough for a slice to hold it's shape.

I also included a teaspoon of finely ground coffee in the graham cracker crust (which is super easy to make; crush a package of graham crackers and mix with melted butter. Job done!) Really gives it a nice flavor to offset the citrus!

Also, don't look for bubbles because you'll never see them. DO NOT try to cook this for more than 10 minutes. There's no egg to cook here.

Thanks for this recipe!

country:

text:
Super easy for someone who doesn't make pies!  I have made this pie 3 times in 2 weeks.  The first pie I used 3/4 cups of Nellie & Joe's Famous Key West Key Lime Juice vs. squeezing limes (no time/no patience) and left out the zest.  I only used 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk (14oz) based on other reviews.  I thought the pie was good, but very, very tart. So I made another one to take to a cookout the next day.  This time I did everything the same as above but cut back and only used 2/3 cup of the Key Lime Juice and threw in a pinch of salt.  To my surprise there was a "Key Lime Pie Connoisseur" in attendance. ugh!  She talked and talked about where the "BEST" Key lime pie was in Florida..blah blah...  So I held my breath when she went for a slice.  She later approached me and said, "That was one of the BEST Key Lime Pies I have ever had!"  SCORE one for ME!  I had many more compliments that day over the pie. My husband who isn't a fan of Key Lime even said, I don't know what you did different with this second pie but it was fantastic.  I think using a little less of the Key Lime juice did the trick, I guess the stuff in bottle is a little more potent then what you get from fresh squeezed.  

Pie #3 was just for my family and YUMMY!  I do like to keep it in the freezer and eat it very, very chilled w/a little whipped cream.

Nellie and Joe's Key West Famous Key Lime Juice; Bakery isle or Juice isle in local grocery stores.

Thank you for a great receipt.

text:
I made this over the weekend. IMHO you must top or garnish this with whipped topping to mellow it out a bit. Juicing 20 key limes and grating about 8 was time consuming but worth it. To juice the limes without a citrus squeezer cut them in half and insert a fork and twist and press! If making your own graham cracker crust I wouldnt add additional sugar. Just a sleeve of graham crackers in the food processor with 6 TBS melted butter. Oh and let the pie come to room temp before chilling to avoid it seperating from the crust.

this recipe is so incredibly 5 star!  i have been making key lime pie with egg yolks for so many years and thought it would be almost impossible to turn out good without them..maybe the wrong consistency with none.  was i ever wrong about that! i followed the recipe to a tee using 20 key limes and baked for 12 minutes.  i did not notice the tiny pinhole bubbles until after it cooled, topped it with fresh whipped cream made with heavy cream whipped with a tablespoon of sugar topped with a sprinkle of key lime zest.  the consistency of the pie was creamy firm and tastes like the best key lime pie i have ever eaten with rave reviews from my daughter and friends. it has the perfect balance between sweet and tart as in 50/50. what inspired me to make my own this time was seeing, are you ready, FROZEN key lime pie in key west from a key lime pie store for $18.95! and they top it with meringue. (yuck) this recipe is the absolute best and i will always use this recipe, and thanks for it!

text:
this key lime pie is great, i followed the recipe and it is veeeeery yummy!
a few tips:
if you are making a graham cracker crust, make sure to make it with 2 cups of crumbs... that way you have a thick crust that doesnt break that easily
make sure to bake the crust before filling it with the key lime mixture.. bake for 8 minutes 
let the crust cook at room temperature and fill with the key lime mixture.. put it in the fridge for an hour and then bake for 10 minutes.. I made this with the meringue II recipe on this site.. I preheated the oven and made the meringue, then put it on the unbaked chilled pie and baked for 10 minutes.
great!

text:
Key lime pie is made with egg yolks. Everybody knows that. This recipe has no egg yolks, so it can't be real Key lime pie, right? That was what I figured, but then I saw the huge number of overwhelmingly positive reviews. So I tried it. And it was great. Light, but not overly fluffy, consistency, with a perfect blend of sweet and tart. It set up perfectly and sliced neatly. 

Perhaps if I tried it next to a more traditional recipe, I'd notice a difference, but I don't know if I'll ever make a more traditional recipe again, because this was so easy and so good. 

A few notes: I used an extra-large, store-bought graham cracker crust. I was worried there wouldn't be enough filling, but there was exactly enough. It would have been too much for a regular-sized crust. Also, I used regular limes instead of Key limes, which my supermarket didn't carry. I found that two cans of sweetened condensed milk was the perfect amount.

Paula Todora (Paula T)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5594110.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
READ THESE TIPS before making since squeezing the limes is the most time-consuming part! #1 Microwave 8-10 key limes 30-40 seconds before squeezing. They'll be warm to the touch, and when you cut them open they'll burst with juice, making it much easier to hand squeeze into a measuring cup. #2 Microwave 8-10 at a time but cut 5 open while warm and squeeze while warm. Then cut another 5 open and squeeze while warm. As they cool after cut, it gets harder to squeeze them. While they're warm, the juice just comes pouring out. #3 Don't worry about the seeds until after ALL juice is measured-then pour through a wire mesh strainer or tea strainer. Goes faster this way.   These are my lime squeezing tips because it's the most annoying part. The rest is easy-so few ingredients and so wonderful. Tastes like restaurant quality pie. You'd think you're visiting The Florida Keys! Make your own whipped topping and make your own pie crust please. It makes it mo bettah. I also have additional photos on my blog paulajeancuisine.com

text:
I started out making it as written, so here goes. I made my own basic graham crust. I used 2 cans of SCM (24oz = 3 cups, right?) but didn't scrape them out. Mixed in sour cream (full fat for texture. lowfat is more watery), then poured in lime juice. Tasted as I went (you can do that, ya know), and ended up adding a good bit more lime juice and another Tbs sour cream to get the taste I wanted. Baked for 15 minutes, and it came out of the oven pretty firm with a few tiny bubbles on the surface. Chilled it in the fridge for 5 or 6 hours, and topped it with a lightly sweetened, homemade whipped cream to cut the richness. It was delicious! Nice and firm, exactly the light, creamy texture I expect in a key lime pie. Definitely taste the mixture as you blend it, and add more lime juice as you see fit.

I live in Florida and I have a key lime tree I my back yard so I have key limes year round and this is a great recipe and I also like to make candied  key lime zest for the top gives it that special something my husband loves my pies even his work is asking for them he goes to work and they always ask what I am making lately I have been on a homemade ice cream fix I made key lime ice cream who new it would be a big hit just take the key lie pie mix and refrig over night and but into ice cream maker of your choice I use the kitchen aid ice cream maker I make gram cracker crumbles to put on top it is great give it a try either way key lime pie is awesome and I was just looking at some of the pics for this pie no key lime pie is not green and it is made only in a gram cracker crust and do not put whipped cream all over it just some little flowerets along the edge and one in the middle with a candied slice of key lime not a reg lime please this is a native Florida dish and we love are key lime pie and each recipe has been handed down sorry it does take a lot of time to zest and juice these little gems but it is truly worth it and please no food coloring a native Floridian will not touch a green key lime pie because it I fake we all know this the only green should be the zest and that is it.

An excellent result for very little effort. We had Key Lime Pie in Maraton, FL last month and I couldn't wait to make it at home. This recipe tasted exactly as I remembered. Display Name:

isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2157478.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy!  I used a ginger snap crust from another recipe because I didn't have graham crackers to make the crust.  Anyway, the ginger snap crust was perfect for the pie.  In case anyone is interested, this is what I did:  Mix 1 Cup finely crushed ginger snaps & 3 T melted butter.  Press into bottom and up sides of 9" pie plate, bake at 375 degrees for 10 to 12 minutes.  Cool completely before filling.  I loved the tip about using a garlic press to squeeze the limes!  I hand squeezed them just enough to fit them into my garlic press and was amazed at how much more juice I got out of each lime!  Update:  The crust was a bit thin.  Next time I will use 1 1/2 Cups crushed gingersnaps and 4 1/2 T butter.

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2012-08-17T07:32:07.483

text:
SO easy, SO creamy, and SO, SO delicious! This pie was a hit and went fast (although, I must say I ate 2 slices, it was that good). Very refreshing desert for a summer party. I wanted to make this easier on myself (I'm a bit of a lazy cook), so I purchased key lime juice instead of juicing key limes myself. I used 3/4 C+ 1 Tbls of the juice, just to make sure there was enough flavor since I did not have any zest. It came out perfect. I baked mine for 10 min exactly, I did not even bother trying to look for pinhole bubbles. Thanks for a super easy (and fool-proof) recipe!

city:

country:
None
text:
Oh my, this was really yummy!  This recipe has been discussed a lot on the Buzz lately, so I decided I had to try it.  I made my own graham cracker crust and used an 8” springform pan, rather than a pie plate, which worked quite well.  Not wanting to have a partial can of sweetened condensed milk leftover, I used two cans, which made me shy about 1/2 cup, according to my calculation, but it didn't seem to matter.   I ended up baking this for about 10 minutes, waiting for tiny bubbles to appear but they never did.  This set up beautifully and cut cleanly.  In hindsight next time I will bake my graham cracker crust first at 350 for 8-10 minutes, cool and proceed with the recipe.  Also, if you’re using a springform pan like I did, be sure to run a hot knife around the sides of the pan before removing the ring.  This was excellent and refreshing on a hot summer day!

userID:

Display Name:
Post-It Poet

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! I have made this recipe probably 10 or 12 times in the last 2 summers, and everyone loves it! I always make a homemade graham cracker crust, because it's just so easy and tastes so much better than a premade one. The only thing I change is that I use 1 full cup of key lime juice (Nellie's in the bottle) and 1 full cup of sour cream. I lighten it up a little by using light/low-fat sour cream and 2% reduced fat sweetened condensed milk. (I think the fat free is really grainy, but the 2% retains a flavor and texture that is close to the full fat, especially after combined with the sour cream and lime juice.) This usually is enough for a full pie plus I make a few "tartlets" in a cupcake tin  with graham crust and filling, which kids always seem to like!

text:
I've always been known for my key lime pies so trying a new recipe didn't seem necessary. Boy was I wrong....this is incredible...and no eggs..WOW 
it couldn't be easier and the taste is perfection...not too sweet or tart. Everyone loved it. thank you for giving me a new and improved Key Lime Pie. I made my own crust using gingersnaps and pecans, crushed fine in food processor with sugar and butter. Instead of pie  pan I made this in a 9" springform pan. looks like a cheesecake when done. Also I've tried this with 2 and 3  cans condensed milk, with 2 cans the pie was much more tart. If you prefer a more subtle lime flavor use 3 cans. Either way it is the best and easiest  key lime pie ever.

text:
Five stars are not enough for this recipie.I didn't have graham crackers so i used a cheese cake base and yogurt instead of sour cream.It took me only 6 limes for the amount of juice that is need it.I have no idea what you girls did with 20 or 30 limes.Here is a small tip for squeezing limes and lemons.Before you do it press and roll them with your palm to soften.This way you can get all the juice out of them very easy.I also didn't get any bubbles so I ended up cooking it for about 20 min.I had 17 limes and now i have 11 left for another 2 pies.I love it.Thank you

country:
None
text:
I cannot rave enough about this pie, I've made it many times now and it turns out fantastic each time.  It is SO easy and quick to prepare, and it sets perfectly and has a beautiful presentation with just a dollop of whipped cream and a twist of lime on top of each slice.  The flavor is wonderful, with plenty of lime but it is not overwhelming at all, and the texture is so creamy.  I have made it both with and without the lime zest, it does not do too much to the flavor but adds nice specks of color to the pie, although its just beautiful without them.  Be sure to bake it just until you see the tiny pinhole bubbles on top, they are a bit hard to see, so you really have to watch for them.  I have made this pie with both a graham cracker and shortbread crust, and both are wonderful.  This pie is a permanent favorite in our house!

This stuff is amazing!  I served it at a dinner party and everyone loved it.  My husband's coworker suggested I enter it into the company dessert competition. This is the absolute BEST key lime pie I've ever had.  It is definitely restaurant quality...maybe even better!  It's so easy and quick to make too.  I used a store bought graham cracker crust and bought key lime juice.  Don't waste your time juicing all those limes!! None
text:
This was my first selfmade key lime pie ever. It turned out perfect! All my guest loved this pie - it was practically gone in no time. My mom already ordered one for her birthday ;) As I am from Germany and had to replace some ingredients as they are not available over here: I used persian limes. You need about 5 to get enough juice, but I used the grated rind of 10.  As they are sweeter in taste I added a dash of concentrated lime juice (Citrovin) to get a "limier" taste. Finally I replaced the sour cream with - literally -  sour cream (I think German sour cream is slightly different from American (less fat)). I topped the pie with a mixture of slightly sweetened whipped cream and crème fraîche (1/4 liter each), stiffened with a little gelatin (2 pieces). This definitely is a keeper!

text:
I loved this key lime pie, and it turned out perfectly--even with some of the changes and substitutions I made.  I used 1/2 c. fresh lime juice and 1/4 c. lemon juice for the key lime flavor.  I was short one can of condensed milk, and so I made my own my heating 1 c. evaporated milk and 1 1/4 c. sugar until the sugar disolved.  My other can of condensed milk was Skim.  Even with fake key lime juice, homemade condensed milk, and skim condensed milk, it was GREAT.  I do *highly* recommend making your own graham cracker crust.

text:
This is the EASIEST, most IMPRESSIVE pie EVER!  Seriously, the only labor involved at all is the squeezing of the limes, which I used another's suggestion and did it with a garlic press.  (Yields way more juice.)  After the limes are squeezed, you can do the rest in your sleep and in only 8 minutes baking and a quick hour of cooling right from the oven to the fridge, you have a pie that is simply devine!!!!!

country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe!  A few changes:  I used a combo of fresh lime,fresh lemon, and bottled key lime juice to equal 3/4 cups. Also, I used half cream cheese and half sour cream to equal 1/2 cup.  I used 2 cans of condensed milk.  More would have been too much. Everything but the zest went into the Vitamix. I stirred in almost one tablespoon of lime zest.  Super easy!  I made a shortbread cookie  crust  with Lorna Doones cookies.  Baked the pie for 10 minutes like some reviewers suggested and once cooled, refrigerated the pie overnight.  It set up perfectly and very creamy.  This was my husbands birthday dessert and he loved it.

My husband is the cook and baker of the family. Most of the time when I cook I get "it's alright". I made this for our anniversary b/c he loves Key Lime Pie and this is his response: "This is the best thing you have EVER made".  I didn't add the grated lime zest because I couldn't find key limes and I used Nellie & Joe's Famous Key Lime Juice.  Also used a large premade graham cracker crust. It was so easy to make, too. I am not allowed to make it again for "a month or 2" because he just keeps eating it. Every time I turn around he has another piece. Definitely my go to recipe from now on!

text:
This was an absolutely amazing AND simple pie to make! I used homemade condensed milk, regular limes and non-fat Greek yogurt for the sour cream. That is an improvement in terms of calories and nutrition! (Because it's Greek yogurt the texture is the same as sour cream.) It's a win-win swap for a delicious pie! FYI: It WAS challenging to know when exactly it should come out of the oven however.

text:
Made this earlier today. LOVED IT! The only changes I made was that I used 28oz (2 whole cans) of the condensed milk and I baked it for 10 mins rather than 5-8. It came out perfectly. I didn't have any Florida Key Limes, so I used Nellie & Joe's Famous Key West Lime Juice. This has been added to my recipe box and will be made many more times in the future.

UPDATED COMMENT: Question... Has anyone been able to get the tiny pin holes to appear???? I have made this now about 20 times. I have baked it for as long as 20 minutes and still no pin holes. Thankfully, the pie has always come out very well regardless. Just curious.

text:
My 9YO daughter had a presentation to give on Florida and one of the extra credit points is to bring in a food for the place they are presenting. I found this recipe and I must say, it was amazing!!!! I made a pie before bringing one to the school and brought it to work to test on the co-workers, the pie got rave reviews! I followed the recipe exactly. The most vague part was the cooking time, my daughter and I camped out in front of the oven for about 20 minutes waiting for that perfect bake time. If anyone has a problem with this pie it is because they either cooked the pie improperly or they didn't USE REAL KEY LIME juice. A garlic press is so super helpful for this recipe. 20 key limes made the right amount of juice; zest is essential; I used pre-made crust from Keebler, no complaints on that either.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never made nor eaten key lime pie before, but after moving to a house with a key lime tree in the yard, I decided I needed to do something with them. Due to my husband's dietary restrictions (strict low-fat, gluten-free), I appreciated that this recipe doesn't use eggs. I made the recipe exactly as written, using fat-free sweetened condensed milk and fat-free sour cream in the filling, and fat-free whipped topping. For the crust I used gluten-free graham style animal crackers (cheaper than the gluten-free graham crackers), low-fat butter substitute, and equal parts sugar and Splenda. Like others, I baked for 10 minutes and the pie turned out superb! I doubt anyone would know by the taste that it's virtually a fat-free dessert!

userID:
1393435
Display Name:
Mel

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always thought that Key Lime Pie would be hard to make, but this was so easy to make and I loved it.  I have made about 12 so far and everyone said they like it, so far.  One lady said her husband wanted to eat the whole thing and only left her a small slice.  I am so happy I found this recipe, as I live very close to the keys and I see that the store has these key limes for months now.  Happy that I found fresh key limes every time.  The last time I made it I wasn't home, so the grater that I was using made the zest too large and when you bit into it in the pie, it was too large of a piece of zest, so I would suggest that your grater makes really tiny bits of zest. Tastes better that way.  One time I accidentally used the entire two cans of sweetened condensed milk, and that was just 4 ounces more than the recipe called for.  It still tasted good, but a little milky, so don't make that mistake I made.  Also, one time, I bought the large pie crust at the store, and the pie didn't fill it well, so don't do that either. Buy the smaller pie crust. Also, use real key limes and nothing else.  This is important for this pie. Thank you for this recipe!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Gotta love how easy this is!  Have made this pie three times now, each one slightly different, followed the original recipe other than where noted.  1) Swapped 8oz of "whipped" cream cheese in for one can of the SCM per another reviewers suggestion, only 2tsp lime zest - too tart for my tastes since it's missing half of the SCM, but it set beautifully and the texture was great.  2) Stuck to the original recipe - came out very good but maybe a tad too sweet and the texture wasn't quite as nice as the previous cream cheese version [rate this recipe 4.5 stars].  3) Somewhere in the middle; 2 cans SCM, nearly 1 cup key lime juice, 4oz whipped cream cheese and a larger graham crust that says "2 extra servings" on the label (fit perfectly) - Delicious!  Baked all 3 times at 350 for about 12-14 mins, no browning.  Used bottled "Nellie & Joe's Key West Lime Juice" and, couldn't help myself, 1 drop of green food coloring just because I think it looks pretty.  Tried a shortbread crust once, but personally prefer the more hearty graham crust.  GREAT recipe overall that was a JOY to experiment with, thank you for sharing it!

text:
This pie was really good.  I decided to make the crust from scratch using a recipe from this site.  It took about 20 limes to make 1 1/2 cups juice - believe me that was the hardest part, squeezing all those limes!  Someone on this site suggested using a garlic press and smooshing each lime half into the press and squeezing it that way, that worked very well.  Everyone asked for seconds on the pie, it was a big hit!

text:
I agree with everyone about how delish the pie is, and easy as well, but 2 cans gives you a little more than 2 cups, not three, I had to run out to buy a third to make pie as recipe states,  I do have less than half can left, but hey, 3 Cups is 3 cups, not little over 2.  I used regular limes as well, maybe took about 6 nice size limes.  It looks lovely, nice and full in a Keebler shortbread crust.  And I have a convection oven, and I cooked it 8 min.  I didn't see bubbles either, but I giggled it and it seemed set.  Conv. cooks 5 min. less pretty much anyway, but I did do 8 min. 
Can't wait to try it.  I have made it a few times before but gave them away to friends, this one is mine, all mine.
Enjoy :)

text:
I've tried about 10 different key lime pie recipes and this is the one that's been most preferred by my picky pie-eating boyfriend!  Many other recipes use egg yolks and it seems that something about that addition takes away from the authentic Key West version of the pie.  As other users have said, 3/4 cup key lime juice takes a lot of key limes!  But the result is worth it.  I top mine with a classic homemade whipped cream recipe (heavy whipped cream, vanilla, and sugar).

text:
I have never eaten a key lime pie before, and since I wanted to make one for my boyfriend, I wanted to take the challenge and make my very first pie (which I do not have any knowledge of what the taste should or shouldn't be). 

This pie's recipe is so simple but man does it turn out SO AMAZINGLY. 
My only tip for people who are going to try it out is to pay attention to the amount of cream you put into the crust. You want to make sure that it won't over-flow or be too much.

Have fun making this very easy-to-do pie. It is so delicious!!!

text:
I have never eaten/made a key lime pie before using this recipe, and to be completely honest, I don't think I will ever use/eat another recipe, apart from this one, for as long as I live.  THIS WAS DELICIOUS!!!
Yes, it is incredibly tedious to squeeze all those little limes, but oh-so worth it!  Thanks to a fellow reviewer, I used a garlic press to help with the juicing process (ALL HAIL THIS REVIEWER!!!), and it probably saved me an hour in itself!  
I don't know if it the limes were simply out of season, but I called every single grocery/health food store in town, in search of key limes, and Schnucks was the only store that carried them!  
Regardless, this recipe in to die for, and I will absolutely make it again!!!

Also, I used the "Graham Cracker Crust I" recipe on here in lieu of a store bought crust - the two went together perfectly!!!

Thanks for sharing!

This must be one amazing pie.  I screwed up the recipe and it still came out good.  I forgot the 3rd can of sweetened condensed milk (on the phone and trying to bake at the same time).  I also forgot to stir in the lime zest so I sprinkled it on top.  The pie sat up nicely.  It was really good and no one thought it needed any more milk.  They wouldn't have known the difference if I hadn't told them.  I did make my own graham cracker crust and it was delish with a little allspice in it.  Was out of cinnamon.  This recipe is a keeper if you like Key Lime. I've made this for the second time now and did everything right this time. Even BETTER! Be sure to measure out 3 cups of sweetened condensed milk. It will take not quite 3 cans.  If you just pour 3 cans in you will be using too much and it probably won't set up. My pie set up nice and firm. Used cinnamon in my crust this time, also very good.

None
text:
I love key lime pie and I love citrus flavors. This is the ONLY key lime pie recipe I use now. It's soooo easy to make and very fast. I add extra zest just because I love lime, and when I use the extra-large graham cracker crust pie shell ("2 extra servings!") I can use 3 cans of condensed milk (so no leftovers to rot in the fridge!). I just add an extra spoon of sour cream and up the lime juice to 1 Cup. I haven't been able to mess this recipe up yet, so if you're scared you might, try this recipe. It's totally foolproof and makes me totally feel like a cook :)

text:
Great recipe!

To not waste sweetened condensed milk, I used just  two cans (28 oz) and set the serving size to 6.  (I did this and had the perfect amount of filling).

If you're making the crust by hand, make sure to make the edges high (so the filling doesn't "flood" over the pie crust).

This key lime pie is excellent. Anyone can make this with great results. I used a Keebler premade Graham pie crust. And I used Nellie & Joes Key West Lime Juice. The juice came in a 16 oz. bottle so I will be making a few more pies. 

This pie turns out every bit as good as the ones I buy from the bakery. I will never buy another one now that I know how to make it myself.

Thanks so much for sharing this excellent recipe. It is also very easy to make. It takes no time at all! YUM!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am lactose intolerant and don't particularly care for key lime pie myself, but my wife loves it so I thought I'd make this one based on the reviews... OMG!!! This pie was SOOOO A-MAZING!!! I got a little of the filling on my hands as I was filling the shell. It was so good, I had to reserve a few spoons to "sample" as the pie set. I made the pie using fat free condensed milk and sour cream, as well as reduced fat crust, so it's not so sinful! Still tastes GREAT!!! Didn't have a zester, so I didn't worry about the lime zest and the pie is still PLENTY limey. 2 cans and 20 limes makes the perfect amount of filling and the consistency was beautiful! Brought a few samples to work and it was a HIT! Thanks to all those who suggested the garlic press. Worked like a charm! One last thing, be sure to use room temperature limes. Next time, I'll try it using homemade crust and whipped cream. Thanks again for a definite keeper!!!

text:
This is an amazing pie- I would give it more than 5 stars. It is really idiot proof as I have never made keylime pie before until today. I followed the suggestion and reduced the condensed milk to 2 cups, and increase sour cream to just above half cup, and made my own crust.  I had some left over crust material and did mini tartlets using a tart mould. Baked it for exactly 10 minutes (it didnt show any signs on the top but justbake as instructed for 10 minutes)- Perfect!! It was a huge hit at home...definitely a keeper, and tastes better than a lot of restaurant pies.

Display Name:
KMSWEB

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6645378.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an awesome recipe! So much better than any key lime pie I have ever bought from any store. I only needed 15 key limes to get the 3/4 cup of juice, used one of those cheap little manual citrus juicers which is much more efficient than trying to squeeze them with your fingers. Used 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk, came pretty close to the 3 cups called for. Reduced fat sour cream. Used maby 1/2 tsp of zest only because I was too lazy to grate any more than that. Heated for about 10 minutes, didnt really notice any bubbles. Turned out excellent!! Husband was impressed, he loves key lime pie :)
Review:

text:
Delish!  Like most reviewers suggested, I used 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk and it was fine.  I don't know think it would have been too sweet with 3 full cups but you would need the deeper crust because mine went to the top with 2 cans on a regular size crust.  After making and serving this pie a dozen times, I recommend serving whipped cream on the side because some prefer it without the cream (although I love it with!)

text:
Easy and tasty! To make it even easier I used 3/4 cup of 'Nellie & Joe's Key Lime Juice' and a TBS of lime zest from just a normal lime. The 16 oz bottle of juice cost only $3 and saved SO much time and energy! Next time I will omit the lime zest because the lime flavor was almost too strong. I used "Graham Cracker Crust II" from this site which just took it over the top! My whole family loved this dessert!

city:

country:
None
text:
My husband said this was "luscious".  I thought it was very good, but quite rich and needed the whipped cream to soften the impact just a bit.  It set up very well and was easy to cut and looked pretty on the plates.  I would serve it for company, with quite a dollop of whipped cream on top and a little grated lime rind to top it off.  Update:  I tried it with just the two cans Eagle Brand and about 3/4 cup sour cream and used bottled organic lime juice.  Flavor was softened a bit, could taste the sour cream just a little more, and was a little better than the original recipe, I thought.  Next time would go back to the 1/2 cup sour cream, still use just the 2 cans Eagle Brand, and if I'm in a hurry, still go with the bottled lime juice, as it was very good.

text:
Easy and yummy--what more could you ask for?  I was a little nervous at the short cook-time, but with a mere 10 minutes, and then chilling, it was completely set-up inside.  I didn't see many "tiny bubbles" in the surface--I wouldn't use that to gauge the doneness.  Just make sure your oven is at the right temp and follow the directions.  Oh, it's surprisingly rich despite the absence of eggs.  1/8 piece is more than enough.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an awesome key lime pie!  I'm from South Florida and I've always made key lime pie with a different recipe.  I decided to try this recipe on a whim, and it's my new key lime pie recipe. My company, husband, and 20-month-old daughter also raved about this pie.  The only problem with it is staying away from the leftovers in the refrigerator.    I found that two cans of sweetened condensed milk was almost three cups, so I just went with that.  The pie was definitely sweet enough.  It did not need a third can!  I also used regular limes due to the unavailability of key limes, and couldn't tell a difference between the regular limes and key limes.  I do recommend adding the zest.  It enhances the citrus flavor of the pie.  It's also pretty.      Try this recipe, you won't be disappointed.

Made one batch in a 13x9 dish--just thick enough; double the recipe if you want the height of a traditional pie using 13x9. Got lots of requests for this recipe after serving it to a group of ladies.  My first time making key lime pie; Key Lime Pie VII rates signature status in the recipe file.

text:
I have now made this pie MANY times, and every time it comes out perfectly.  I have also substituted lemon juice/zest...great lemon pie.  I add a dollop of vanilla yogurt and use fat free condensed milk and fat free sour cream.  Best with a homemade graham cracker crust.  I would recommend this to anyone!  EDIT:  Will not make this without Greek yogurt again - it adds an element that sour cream doesn't quite cover.  I like the Greek yogurt much better.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing! I love that it's lime-y and not overly sweet-- too many key lime pies taste more like condensed milk than lime, in my opinion. I used half lemon juice and half regular lime juice because I couldn't find any key lime juice, and just 2 cans of condensed milk (which is a little under 3 cups). It made the perfect amount of filling for a standard store-bought graham cracker crust, I couldn't imagine needing more milk. I also ended up leaving it in the oven for almost 15 min. because I couldn't see the holes. When I finally took it out I did see some holes, but I had to look really really closely. So don't worry about the holes-- just leave it in for 10-15 min. and you should be good to go. Delicious!

text:
I am not a lime pie fan, but I truly love this pie.  As others did, we juiced 20 key limes in a garlic press and used 2 cans of condensed milk.  We skipped the zest for creaminess' sake.  We also used a sugar free homemade graham cracker crust. (Just leave the sugar out of a regular graham cracker crust recipe--you won't notice, and if you do, then you eat WAY too much sugar!)  Phenomenal! Really! We've been talking about this pie for months! (I know, we need a life, but it is really THAT good!)

country:
None
text:
I've made this pie a total of 3 times now, and I can only say that this is the best key lime pie I've EVER had. The first time I made it, we just sent the limes through a juicer, and it left the pie with a very bitter taste. The other two times, I made it, it turned out PERFECT!! The only thing I changed, was instead of a graham cracker crust, I used crushed Nilla wafers. I've read a few of the reviews that say it was too sweet, or not tangy enough, and  think they might be putting in 3 cans of sweetened condensed milk instead of three cups. It's always turned out just right for me, not too sweet with just the right bite!

Loved this recipe!  This is the first Key Lime Pie recipe I have tried.  I loved the consistancy and flavor.  I left out the rind because I accidentally threw away my limes before getting the zest.  Also, I didn't have a full 3/4 cup lime juice.  Next time around I will be sure to add the zest and the full amount of lime juice to see if that will give it a little more bite than the one I just made.  I loved how easy it was to make!

text:
This came out amazing! Graham cracker pie crusts were on sale, so I cheated and bought one premade. I used 2 and 2/3 cans of evaporated milk, and additional 2 tbs of lime juice (I had squeezed 7 Mexican limes by hand and that was just over 3/4 cup). A tip for squeezing limes: roll them around pressing firmly on a countertop, and when you slice in half, the juice practically gushed out with the slightest squeeze. this is SO creamy and so delicious- you gotta try it!! It hold so well, and set beautifully.

country:
None
text:
If you like "real" key lime pie this is a great recipe.  The 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk that I bought did not make exactly 3 cups so I cut down on the key lime juice just a little.  I used bottled key lime juice and it worked just fine in the recipe.  "Real" key lime pie should not be green as it is in some restaurants.  If it is they have added some food coloring.  The pie should be a very light yellow.  I put cool whip on top and it was delicious.  The cool whip should be put on after it has cooled and been refrigerated for several hours or overnight.  This is a very easy recipe and maybe next time will use fresh key limes that I can get right here in Laredo Tx.

I was hesitant to try this recipe because most key lime pies are just a little off the mark when it comes to taste or texture, and I really did not believe this one (my first attempt at key lime pie on this website) could be "the one". But IT IS!! To save time, I just used lime juice from the squeeze bottle, but if you were to use gourmet ingredients this pie would be heavenly. You HAVE to try it!!!

Display Name:
MICHELEMS

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a number of times  and can't imagine a better key lime pie recipe! Perfect balance of sweet and tart for us and so easy to make. I used 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk and no lime zest, but might use a bit of it for garnish next time. IMHO, Nellie & Joe's Key West Lime Juice is a must if you don't have fresh limes (which I wouldn't bother with). I use the graham cracker crust recipe from this site that others have mentioned and reserve a few crumbs to sprinkle on top.

I forgot to bake it the first time because my previous recipe was a no-bake one. It was totally edible and yummy, though, but more like a custard. I did bake it the second time and it took about 10 minutes.

UPDATE: I recently made this again for my book club, but used 12 clear glass mini-bowls rather than a pie pan to provide more servings and to look a bit fancier. I only had 1/2 cup of N&J key lime juice, so substituted fresh lemon juice for 1/4 cup. I put a dollop of whipped cream and a tiny triangle slice of lime (blot juice with paper towel) on top - they looked so pretty! Guests raved and all but one consumed every last bite. This will now be my new go-to dessert for company. Thank you for sharing, Ann!
UPDATE: I just tried doubling the recipe (crust too) for a 9" x 13" baking dish. Worked great! Garnished with lime zest and baked in convection oven at 325 degrees for 10 minutes.

text:
Based on many of the ratings that said there wasn't enough filling, I added a bit more (proportionally): I added one more cup of the milk (4 cups); 1/4 cup more juice (1 cup), 1/4 cup more sour cream (1 cup).  The only thing I didn't increase is the rind; although I didn't measure it.  I had MORE than what could fit in the pie crust.  I think the other people may have got the larger (traditional) size pie crust--not the nine inch.  Now I have leftover filling, which I plan to use some philo dough inside a cupcake pan and make the rest (I'll probably put some chopped toasted pecans in the bottom).  

At any rate, the pie was a bit hit!  I was asked for the recipe several times.  This biggest confirmation was my man--he is a big dessert person and key lime pie is one of his two favorites.  He insisted that it was fabulous!  Definitely a repeat recipe.  I won't even try to find another.  Although I will make my own crust next time.   Also, I garnished with some wild, freshly picked berries.  Perfect!

This is an awesome recipe! Simple but rich in flavors. I used freshly squeezed lime juice and I also blended some fresh mint leaves. You cannot go wrong with all these fresh stuff. I made the crust with 20 Oreo cookies with chocolate creme. It works well with tartness of the lime filling. text:
Great recipe! I love to experiment. Try it with lemons, it's wonderful. Oranges are a little bit trickier. You have to condense the freshly squeezed orange juice down about 1/3. Just simmer the juice until it's a little bit stronger taste.  Let it cool before adding. I'm not a graham person so my go to butter crust recipe is 1/2 cup butter, softened, 1 1/3 cups all-purpose flour, 1/4 cup white sugar. Mix with a fork until crumbly. Press into pan and bake for 20 minutes.

text:
This pie was so easy to make and came out so delicious, it was a perfect combination of tart and sweetness.  However I did make a few changes, I  squeezed enough fresh limes that I purchased in a bulk bag from Walmart to make about 1 cup of lime juice and I didnt include any lime zest.  Also I let the pie cook in the oven about 10 minutes The receipe was a hit.  I will be making it again soon.

I was skeptical because the recipe looks  too easy but it was fantastic. 2 cans of condensed milk give you a little bit less than 3 cups if you take a small spatula and take absolutely everything out. I didn't bother opening another one because it seemed like a waste. Besides, my little bag of keylimes gave me about 1/8 C less of what I needed so I thought it would work out, and it did!
I bought the "two more servings"  graham craker crust which is a little bit bigger than the regular one and it turned out to be the perfect amount. I had space to put the whipped cream and it looked nice, not like it was going to overflow. Everyone in my house loved it. This recipe is a winner!

pie can be made a day or  2 before company  and still be fresh if need be.

text:
Delicious! I used 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk & Nellie & Joe's Key West Lime Juice. Following another reviewer's recommendation, I baked the pie 10 minutes, turned off the oven & let it sit for 30 minutes; then refrigerated it. After the pie was chilled, I topped it with a smooth mixture of 1/2 c. sour cream & 1/2 c. confectioners sugar (another reviewer's recommendation). I served it with a dollop of whipped cream & a twisted lime slice. 
I have had several Key Lime Pie recipes on file but have now tossed all the others. This is the best one!

text:
Super easy recipe. Couldn't find key limes so had to go with regular limes. I think the intense flavour of key limes is critical for best results but if using regular limes substitute sour cream with plain (unsweetened) Balkan-style yogurt. It gives needed tartness to balance the overly sweet condensed milk and mild regular limes... Note: condensed milk comes in 300ml cans where I am, so I only used 2 cans  and it was definitely sweet enough. Made two batches, including mini pies and they were lapped up at my family Victoria Day holiday gathering.... No leftovers or doggie bags and lots of requests for the recipe. My daughter who us a key lime pie fanatic says it's the best she's ever had. And that says a lot! Thank you, Ann and Allrecipes.com!!

text:
Soooo easy and delicious!  I used a 10" pre-made Keebler graham cracker crust and it was surprisingly tasty.  From other reviewers suggestions, I used 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk vs. trying to measure.  I bought real key lime juice on amazon and it was wonderful and again...easy!  I hadn't zested anything before so I watched a quick tutorial on it and it said to be careful not to get anything but the top layer of the lime - none of the white pith underneath which is very bitter.  I wonder if that was the issue for those whose pie came out bitter.  Baked for 10 minutes, let it cool maybe 30 minutes and put it in the frig for dessert the next day.  Whipped cream and strawberries make it even better.  Really perfect.  Thank you for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie is so simple, yet absolutely amazing!  Brought it to family Easter dinner and everyone loved it, even the most discriminating Key Lime pie lovers in the family.  I made the recipe as is, using 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk, which was perfect.  Key limes were not available, so I used key lime juice (found in the juice section of the grocery store). The juice is made in Florida, and the flavor was wonderful.  I made a homemade graham cracker/shortbread cookie crust which was a great balance to the filling.  Easy to make, 3/4 cup crushed graham crackers, 3/4 cup crushed Lorna Doone cookies, 1/2 cup sugar and 6 Tbsp melted butter.  Bake the crust for 7 minutes and let cool before putting the filling in the crust.  I baked the pie for approx. 12 minutes and it was perfectly set. (we live at high altitude and this was still perfect).  Do take the time use the lime zest, it does add something to the pie.  The next time I make this will be for my daughter's high school graduation party as part of the requested "pie bar".  This pie is definitely a "10" in my book!

I used this recipe for my first attempt at baking a key lime pie (which is my all time favorite dessert).  I used low-fat sweetened condensed milk and low fat sour cream.   The measurements were perfect, and as other reviewers mentioned, twenty key limes were just right, and I added one  extra for good measure! This recipe is flawless and there is no need to look any further, better than any slice I have paid for at a fine restaurant in Florida!!  I can't thank. you enough!!!

text:
First off--this recipe is a winner without any changes to it!  However, I live on a small tropical island where dairy products are not always available, so out of necessity I changed the 1/2 c sour cream to 1/2 c coconut milk and added a teaspoon of lemon juice to the milk and let it sour for five minutes.  I then mixed in 2 T of flour (mixed with a little water so it wouldn't clump) to the coconut milk, 2 cans of sweetened condensed, the lime juice, and the rind, and blended all together in my blender before pouring into the crust.  This turned out amazing!  I love both versions, but the coconut milk really goes well with the lime!

country:
None
text:
Perfect.  Will use this recipe forever.

To those who found it bitter... it may just not be sweet enough for you but, the rind will make it bitter if you zest below the color of the fruit, in this case, lime.  Lightly zest so you just scratch the green off and don't get any white below the green into your zest mix. Within reason, of course. Obviously some may get in but, key limes are so small that zesting one is quick business and it is easy to scrape too many times.

text:
I don't think that I have ever had key lime pie before so I don't have anything to compare this recipe to, but I thought it was delicious.  My girls and I had a good time squeezing the limes.  I'm a little surprised that so many people said 3/4 cup of key lime juice was the equivalent if about 20 limes.  I used ten and it was exactly 3/4 cup.  A little hint to getting the most out juice out of your citrus fruit... Roll it on the counter a few times to break up the pulp.  :)

So easy and SO DELICIOUS and rich and creamy. Doesn't even need Cool Whip. The only thing I had an issue with was cook time - it did not seem to change/"set" when I baked it for the 5-8 minutes and I probably ended up baking it around 15 or more minutes to get the little bubbles on the surface. I use Nellie & Joe's key lime juice which comes in a bottle and they have at my local Giant. I usually leave out the lime zest since I don't have a microplane and it's still delicious!

text:
I made this key lime pie recipe exactly as described, except I made a homemade crust to go under it.  It's absolutely delish; very sweet and very tart at the same time.  Highly recommend if you are a hankering for key lime pie.  In case you are wondering, there is a difference between key lime juice and just regular lime juice.  Don't make this pie without the key lime juice, or it will be lacking some of the tartness one would expect.

text:
It's very rare that I come across a recipe that's both a. Absolutely delicious and b. unbelievably easy to make. This is that recipe. (especially if you cheat like me and use a premade graham crust!)
I found the amount of lime juice to be perfect. I didn't add zest to the filling because I thought the juice was enough upon tasting, but I did make some whipped cream with sugar, a dash of lime juice and vanilla and then grated some zest on top of that. I also garnished the pie with little lime slices.
I used Nellie and Joe's bottled key lime juice....Jewel Osco carries it. :)

text:
My family enjoyed this pie very much but it's  a little bit rich for me. The preparation couldn't get much easier though. It took four Persian limes to get 3/4 cup of lime juice and the zest from two to get a tablespoon full.  **note to Michellica: your pie could have turned out bitter if you included the soft, spongy part (the pith) of the lime when taking the zest off the limes. The pith tends to be quite bitter. You want only the deep green part of the skin, the part right at the surface.

text:
Fabulous pie and I love that this one doesn't have eggs since I'm not an egg fan and could always taste the eggs in other key lime pies.  I used my own graham cracker crust (1 sleeve graham crackers, 4 tbsp melted butter, 2 tbsp sugar, pinch salt) in my deep dish pie pan and baked it for 10 minutes.  The 3 cups of sweetened condensed milk equals 2.5 cans.  I used the bottled Nellie and Joe's Key lime juice.  This is a perfect key lime pie!

text:
Made this for my husband's birthday and we both LOVED it!  I didn't have a zester, so I tried using a potato peeler and a paring knife to get the zest, but it was not working well.  So, there was not even an 1/8 of a teaspoon of zest, and the pie still turned out delicious.  This pie is heavy, sweet and slightly tart ... the way we like it. For some reason, I had to use close to 40 key limes to get the right amount of juice.  And, I made this with the homemade Whipped Cream by Paula. P.S. Buy three cans of condensed milk as others say.  Two cans do not equal three cups, and three cups do not overflow the store-bought Keebler graham cracker crust.

My go-to dessert recipe! I'm a college kid who likes the idea of baking and cooking, but never really had lessons from my mom on how to do either. I love key lime pie so I googled recipes and found this one. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe! We were in the Keys in June and my son had to try Key Lime Pie wherever we went and I have to say this is better than 99% and just as good as the all the pie we tried. 

I did read the reviews and suggestions and made some changes. I only put in one can of the condensed milk. I then put some low fat cream cheese with ff plain yogurt in the food processor...since I didn't have sour cream I added some plain ff kefir. To add a bit more sweetness I used some Agave syrup. The first pie I squeezed limes but the second time I bought the Key lime juice (was less bitter than the limes)  which made 2 pies. For the crust I used graham crackers and almond meal and instead of butter used coconut oil. Awesome! My son said it was one of the best and the party I went to loved the pie also. 

Thanks to all for the suggestions. I love playing around with recipes and trying to make them a bit more healthful.

text:
I've used this recipe verbatim a few times, and I'm simply amazed each time. It's so simple that it almost breaks my brain that it comes out perfect, delicious, and so professional! Every time I've made it, I use a homemade crust (2.25 cups graham crumbs, .5 cup packed brown sugar, 5 oz melted butter), which is crazy good. -- I experimented this time. I love grapefruit, so I decided to try this recipe using fresh grapefruit juice instead of lime. Won't lie, I haven't tried it yet, but it looks and smells perfect. It took 20 minutes in the oven, however, so if you're daring enough to try it, keep that in mind!

text:
Ok, this is the second time I've made this pie. The first one, I would of given it 3 stars. I couldn't find key limes so I went to the liquor store and bought a bottle of key lime concentrate. I forgot to buy a lime so I didn't add the rind in it. I didn't see any bubbles when I baked it. I tasted the pie about 6 hours later after being in the fridge. It was ok. I tasted more of the condensed milk instead of the limes. I, however, did like the firmness. The second time I made this, I did find some key limes in a bag and remembered to buy a lime. I purchased 1 regular condensed milk and one fat free, hoping it would lessen the flavor of the milk. It took a long time to press out the juice of the key limes. I ended up using the whole bag and gave me 1 cup. Everything else was the same. Still no bubbles on the second time, even after 12 mins. The second time was the winner! It was very tart, like the way we like it and full of flavor. No condensed milk flavor at all. It wasn't as firm as the first pie, but I do recommend the pie to be in the fridge for over 6 hours to firm and flavors to gel together. 2 big thumbs up!

text:
Awesome! The flavor was identical to the Key Lime Pie we had for dessert in Key West. I surprised my husband with this pie for Father's Day and he was truly amazed! Our 12 year-old daughter had never had Key Lime Pie and she loved it.
Observation- To achieve a truly authentic Key West Key Lime Pie taste, I used Nellie and Joe's Key West Lime Juice and lime zest ( or lime shaving- that's what I used) is a must. I made one with lime shavings and one without- both excellent, but the one with the lime shavings had the exact Key West Key Lime Pie flavor.
