OMG! This pie is great! The added key lime zest is a perfect addition. I made this pie with the sour cream and then two days later I made another pie, but I used Fage Non-fat Greek Yogurt instead of Sour Cream. Some of the same people had both pies and said it tasted the same after I told them about the substitution. So I'll stick with the Yogurt from now on. If you decide to use yogurt, it has to be thick greek yogurt. Dannon or yoplait isn't going to work as well. Please make your own crust for this pie. It doesn't deserve a store bought.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This might be the best pie I have ever made...and other than the squeezing of 24 key limes (thank goodness for the garlic press), possibly the easiest! I left out the zest because I prefer a creamier texture and blended for a full 2 minutes. Be sure to pick the seeds out of the halved key limes before sqeezing because these seeds are softer and even with the garlic press you can get some seed pulp which is a bit bitter. When cooking, I did not wait for the 'tiny bubbles' but pulled the pie out at exactly 10 minutes, allowed to cool for about an hour - uncovered, and then placed in the frig overnight with a cheesecloth lightly covering so it didn't get soggy on top. Perfect pie!

text:
Yum Yum Yum!!! This was my first go at a key lime pie. There are so many options; I didn’t know which was the “true” key lime pie. I went with this one because it had fresh key lime juice, no green dye or jello, and, just about anything with condensed sweet milk is yummy. I will definitely make it again.  I can’t wait to make it for company! Note: the fresher the key limes, the easier they are to squeeze and the less you will need to squeeze. Some of my key limes had hardened a bit and produced very little juice. Also, the pinholes were hardly there. I cooked it a couple extra minutes just in case and took it out even though I didn’t see any. Lol, my fiancé had a hard time believing I cooked this myself!! It’s crazy how good this was considering how easy it was to make. One of the easiest if not the easiest pie I have ever made.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Please take note that this recipe calls for key limes, not the regular limes in the store!  If you are using regular limes, they are not the same and they do not taste the same. Key limes aren't much bigger than an avocado seed, and they should be yellow in color. Can't find key limes? Buy Nellie and Joe's key lime juice in the juice aisle, it's a good substitution and no squeezing.  Anyway.. this pie was perfect! I followed the directions exactly (using just under 2 cans of condensed milk) and it made a 9" pie to the brim, plus plenty of extra left over to bake in a ramekin without a crust for my gluten free daughter. Both turned out perfectly!  It tasted better than I ever expected. I've had KLP in Key West, so I know what it should taste like. This is really, really close.  8 minutes in the oven is perfect, and make sure you add the zest to the filling. Let it sit overnight in the fridge - this is a must or the flavored won't be fully incorporated. If you love real key lime pie, you won't be disappointed!

Funny how a bunch of these reviews start out with "so I made this for my boyfriend/husband and....." well, because key lime is his favorite, I made this for my boyfriend. He made glorious, "now-I-can-die-happy" faces when he took the first bite, and said it was the best he'd ever had, bar none. 
I also thought it was fantastic: it's super rich, and oh-so-very decadent. The kind of thing you pair with hot coffee or tea. The filling is thick, heavy, creamy, sweet, tangy, and ultra smooth.. (if you're looking for a lighter, fluffier version, IRENED's is also fantastic and not as heavy). 
Bottom line? This was delicious, and I am already being begged to make another one. Wouldn't change a thing.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2012-09-16T15:40:48.45
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
9865892
Display Name:
EvolvingCook
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
16
favoritesCount:
148
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making key lime pie. Based on other reviews, I only used two 14 ounce cans of sweetened condensed milk.

My pie didn't produce any bubbles, but I took it out of the oven after 12 minutes.  Let it cool for 15 minutes, and then put it in the fridge.

I'd recommend definitely leaving it in the fridge overnight, as some other reviewers suggested.  Tasted the pie after two hours in the fridge, and it tasted mostly like sweetened condensed milk with a little sour cream.  However, the next day its tartness came out.  The pie was tasty the next day.

Froze a couple of pieces, and brought them out for guests about a week later.  My guests had good things to say about this recipe.

I'd make this again.

text:
Loved this pie! Key lime is my favorite dessert and I am always looking for a great key lime pie recipe. This is delicious but really is better if eaten the next day or later. I planned on making the recipe as stated and thought 2 cans of milk would equal 3 cups but was a little less. That is all the milk I used however because I don't like a key lime pie that doesn't hold its shape. This amount worked perfectly. I definitely would not leave out the zest. It does give it appeal visually and a little burst of lime that is wonderful with key lime. I also made a homemade graham cracker crust. I personally just think the store bought crust doesn't compare. Finally, I took the suggestion of another reviewer and made a topping out of 1/2 cup sour cream and 1/2 cup confectioners sugar. It was delicious and worked fabulous as a topping to this pie. Thanks for a wonderful recipe!

helpfulCount:

userID:
9174744
Display Name:
vmyselfandi
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
37
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I brought this to a family get together and wanted to make it slightly larger, so I used a 10in" pie pan. I wanted to make it gluten free, so I looked for a GF graham crust. When I could find neither GF graham crust nor GF graham cookies, I decided to use GF shortbread cookies (Shar brand in the yellow bag). I used two 7.5 bags (I left 10 cookies over b/c I didn't feel like I needed that extra bit), mashed them into crumbs (same to about 2 3/4 cups), then combined it with 9tbsp of softened butter and 2tbsp of cane sugar. I pressed in into the 10"pie crust and then poured in the filling (no pre-baking or chilling). The crust was thick - exactly how I wanted it.

I ended up using 3 (14oz) cans of sweetened condensed milk, a tiny bit more than 3/4 cup of lime juice, the same 1/2 cup sour cream and the 1tbsp of lime rind. It ended up being too much filling so I didn't use all of it. Next time, if I do 10" I'll just stick to the same measurements. But aside from that, it came out AMAZING. Everyone loved it. It had the right amount of tartness and creaminess, and the shortbread was a nice compliment to both. I can't wait to make this again.

text:
Divine key lime pie!!  I bought key limes in Arizona while on vacation, just for this purpose.  Made as directed, but with my own crust following others' advice to use 2 C. ground graham crackers and 1/2 C. melted butter.  NOTE:  I used a standard 9-inch Pyrex pie plate, and that amount of graham cracker crust was way too much.  I ended up removing 2/3 C. of the crumbs/butter mixture, which I'll use for something else.  Doesn't get any easier than this, and what a treat!!

For being as simple as this recipe is, there is nothing that beats it! I am constantly on the search for the best Key Lime Pie and nothing has beaten this one since I discovered it. I am known for making this and frequently get requests. People rave about how good it is and I constantly hear how they have never had better. I mix some cinnamon in the crust when I make it (following the recipe for Graham Cracker Crust I) and that gives it a great zing that people love. This recipe is so quick, simple, and delicious, it's amazing!

text:
This key lime pie tasted awesome! The condensed sweetened milk gave the pie a very creamy texture. Yummy! The grated lemon zest gave a special treat in the key lime filling. I used a low fat graham cracker crust to save a few calories; could not notice any difference in the taste of the crust. I used real key limes, squeezed those little buggers with my juicer! I guess there might be key lime juice in a bottle but the real key limes made this pie delicious!

text:
Excellent pie, the best we've had since a particular favorite in the state of Florida (where the hubby and I are from.)  I followed the recipe to the letter with the exception of using regular limes instead of key limes since I can't find any in Hawaii.  My only criticism is that it was a little too sweet, and not tart enough.  This is very possibly explained by the lime difference.  If making it again with regular limes, I would probably use just two cans of sweetened condensed milk instead of using all three cups.  Several others mentioned they used two cans since it was easier and it worked well.

text:
This pie tastes like lime flavored condensed milk  but it doesn't even have enough lime flavor either.  It will pass, but my dad, whom will normally eat ANYTHING, thought how strongly it tasted like the condensed milk!  Do yourself a favor and use the Key Lime Pie recipe on the side of the key lime juice bottle. But if you are going to make this recipe, use the 10" prepared graham cracker crust.  Otherwise you'll have lime flavored condensed milk pudding left over!

Fantastic taste, and really easy.  A word of warning though -- this is not a pretty pie.  It comes out to be a sort of pale beige with green flecks from the lime zest. text:
This is my go-to Key Lime Pie recipe! It’s so easy and always impresses! I buy 4 regular oil’ plain limes—I use the juice from 3 limes, use the zest from 1 lime for inside the pie, and the zest from the leftover to garnish. Don’t forget to save a thin line slice for garnish!! I usually whip up my own cream for the topping to ensure it’s not too sweet. The slightly sweet fresh cream topping really lends to the tartness of the pie. Yay!

text:
Excellent . I baked it a little longer than suggested so  the crust would get more toasted. My whole family enjoyed it. I used 7 1/2 small limes (I have an electric squeezer) and 2 cans of condensed milk. You don't need eggs. Leave it sitting in the fridge for 2 hours. It will eventually become firm and easy to cut with a knife. Note: The second time I made it used 24 key limes but I prefer the small limes instead since they are easier to squeeze. Squeezing 24 little limes is not fun.

text:
This always gets rave reviews from my family- it is the best key lime pie I've ever eaten. These are the changes I've made which I recommend: I make a homemade graham cracker crust (Graham cracker Crust I from this website), I use 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk and don't worry about measuring 3 cups, I add a couple extra tablespoons of lime juice, and I zest an entire lime and add in it (I want it to taste like lime!). Then I make homemade whipped cream and top with 1 sliced lime and add more lime zest on the top of both flavor and decor. It is beautiful! My family says it is the perfect amount of lime....try this you won't be disappointed!

text:
Absolutely Fabulous Recipe!! I used the 3 cups sweetened condensed milk as directed (almost 3, 14oz cans, made just over 3 cups), a Keebler Pre Made Graham Cracker Crust (“with 2 extra servings”), Nellie and Joes Key West Key Lime Juice, and 1tbs of freshly grated lime zest. I also squeezed a whole key lime for extra tartness. I baked for 10minutes and while the pin bubbles were hard to see initially they were there and didn’t burst. This was absolutely delicious. This has become a permanent family dish! I’ll never buy a store bought key lime pie ever again. I finished it off by having a bit of fun (I was inspired by another posters photo of a palm tree decoration) and created a palm tree on my pie as well. I do live in South Carolina after all lol. And of course all topped with yummy whip cream. Thank you so much for posting this recipe. It’s definitely going to be the star of many family occasions!

text:
It was going well until the part where bubbles are supposed to pop after 6 to 8 minutes of baking.  Well I continued baking and baking and baking, checking every 2 minutes, and the bubbles never popped, and the filling stayed runny.Tasted good... like a very sweet key lime pie, maybe a little too sweet, but it certainly needs something to firm it up.  After reading many reviews and watching Allrecipe's video, I'm convinced that the 3 cups of condensed milk the recipe calls for is too much.  Many positive reviewers said they only used 2 cans of condensed milk, and in the video they only used 2 cans (which is about 2 3/4 cups). Arius Hung's modifications sound worth trying (1 can condensed milk + 8 oz of cream cheese instead of 3 cups condensed milk... and blend it all up with a blender) so I might try that.

text:
We just returned home from the Keys a few weeks ago and I really wanted to try my hand at making a Key Lime pie for Easter after having sampled it at five different restaurants in the Keys.     After looking a many recipes, I decided on this one even though it wasn’t strictly traditional.   Another reviewer stated that two cans of sweetened condensed milk are three cups.  I measured very carefully and scraped the cans out and it was short by almost a ½ cup.   I decided to stick with the recipe using ¾ cup lime juice anyways as I didn’t want to risk it being too sweet.   I put it in the preheated oven and no pin sized bubbles appeared let alone burst at five minutes.  I cooked it for 20 minutes and it started to ever so slightly brown on the edges so I pulled it out immediately.  I cooled to room temp and then put in the fridge overnight.   The consistency was perfect upon serving but it was slightly too tart for my taste. I think I will try two cans with 2/3 cup lime juice next time.

Can't say I wasn't a bit skeptical at first - a pie with only 5 ingredients? Get out of here! However, I was totally, totally wrong. This is the best, simplest recipe for key lime pie. I didn't have key limes, so I used regular limes. It still tasted great. My lemon juicer saved me from endless lime squeezing. I kneaded the limes a bit beforehand so they'd be easier to squeeze. text:
This is a fantastic recipe because it is SUPER EASY and tastes great! I have made it a few times. Tonight, my grocery store did not have any key limes, so I just had to buy the regular larger ones. It took 9 regular limes. Honestly, I could not tell the difference. Key limes are supposed to be sweeter, but with all the sweetened condensed milk in here (2 cans) the pie is plenty sweet even with regular limes. 
This pie absolutely needs home made whipped topping on the top of it. Just whip a pint of heavy cream with 3 T. sugar added into it. Whip until thick, put in a ziplock bag with a tiny corner cut off so that you can pipe it on the top. Perfection every time!

Sweet, tangy, creamy.  Juuuust right.  
Note: zest is optional in my opinion, and I think the pie looks better w/o it.  I think whipped cream on top is also optional.
  Try making mini pies like I did!  :)  Bake them for 5 minutes on a tray together (you can buy the mini pie crusts in packs of 6).

text:
I have made this recipe twice now and I just can't get enough of it.  Sooo yummy and sooo easy!  The first time I made it I used a store bought graham cracker crust (mistake!) and used Mexican limes because that was all I had.  Honestly, other than the crust, I thought the Mexican limes tasted just fine.  So, the second time I made it, I used another reviewer's suggestion of replacing one of the cans of condensed milk with an 8 oz. tub of whipped cream cheese.  Divine!  I will be making it that way from now on...with the homemade graham cracker crust, of course.  I can't wait for another "pie" holiday to come around so I have an excuse to make this again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I never made Key Lime Pie before, and I swept the prizes at a pie bake off contest at work with this pie. I had several changes though. 

I made the crust with 1/2 c roasted macadamia nuts, 4 T coconut oil, and 1 packet of crushed graham crackers: press into pan and bake 10 min. 

For the filling, I used about twice as much zest. 

For the topping, I used Emeril's recipe- mix 2 T powdered sugar into 1 c sour cream, and spread it on top after the pie has been chilled for about 2 hours in the fridge. In the morning a put a ring of zest around the outside of the pie, made an overlapping circle of lime slices, and put a few raspberries in the middle. 

It was amazing, there was none left, and people were asking for the recipe! I will definitely make again!

text:
Either juice whole limes (or a combination of Key and "regular" limes) or do not make this recipe! I'm not kidding. I've also made the recipe with just Mexican ((not Key), it was very good, maybe even better)).Do not use bottled lime juice!
I recommend homemade graham cracker crust, but that is your choice.
Whisk the ingedients well and skip the baking, just chill for several hours. And do not use low- or non-fat whipped topping, it will ruin the fresh citrusy flavor.

After reading a couple of the reviews for this recipe,  I chose it to use the fresh key limes I purchased yesterday.  It took my husband & me ONE HOUR to juice enough limes for 1 cup!!!  A 15-minute prep time is unrealistic if you are using fresh KEY limes (which are tiny compared to regular limes.)  And, let me add, if it weren't for one of the reviewer's suggestions to use a garlic press, it would have taken even longer!  So keep that in mind if you are going for the authentic Key Lime Pie.

text:
This was so good and so easy! I went overboard and used all 3 cans of condensed milk, didn't know what to do with that tiny bit left and didn't want to waste!  It does take LOTS of limes, but is so good.  I too waited for what seemed forever for the tiny bubbles to appear... finally they did around the edge and I took it out. It took at least 10 minutes, maybe a little more.. I wouldn't wait longer than that or the texture changes. We loved it without the whipping cream, but if you find it tart, have some whipping cream on hand... Perfect! yummm! turned out good the first time :)

text:
Made this last night, was a little worried about how it was going to turn out because I only had 2 fresh limes in my fridge, but I had to have some key lime pie!  I used the juice from the 2 limes I had and substituted Roses sweetened lime juice for the rest.  I also only had light sour cream on hand, but I did have a box of Graham cracker crumbs, so I made my own crust.  I found like other reviewers that 2 - 14oz. Cans of the condensed milk was plenty(just make sure to get every bit of milk out of the cans). Baked as directed, but found mine took about 9-10 min, could just be my oven.  Yum!  This pie came out so terrific, I was worried for nothing!  Next time I will try using all fresh limes though, would like to see if it's even better.  Thanks for the great recipe!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent. I love this pie, and am experimenting with lower-fat versions (though this is still great compared to the egg-yolk-and-heavy-cream versions!) I've had good luck slowly substituting low-fat sweetened condensed milk. Also, this recipe is easy to increase for a 10" pie crust: 4 cups s.c. milk, 3/4 cup sour cream, 1 cup key lime juice, etc. My only comment is that i find the amount of lime zest a bit excessive (not to mention a pain to grate)-- I use about 1/2 T. zest, even for the larger recipe. Kudos to ANNRICHARDSON!

country:
None
text:
Loved this recipe. Good and tangy - exactly what I was looking for. And it's super easy. I used fresh key limes and three cups of sweetened condensed milk (almost 3 cans). With the leftover filling - there was a good bit, I made 4 key lime pie cones using Keebler waffle cones that I wrapped in foil, stood around the edge of an oven safe saucepan and baked for about 10 minutes at 350. Be sure to remove the foil after baking so the cones don't get soggy.  After they were chilled, I topped with fresh whipped cream. My children loved them.

country:
None
text:
This was super easy and could be a quick way to make key lime pie.  The key limes that I got didn't have much juice so after trying to juice 4 of them I gave up and used bottled lime juice instead, which saved me a lot of time.  The first batch I made I stuck with the recipe with the lime juice change and I found it too sweet, so I modified what I had leftover and added some cream to it and another 1/4 cup of lime juice and that was much better.  I think next time I might use only one cup of condensed milk and use maybe evaporated milk or cream for the remaining difference.

This recipe calls for 3 cups of sweetened condensed milk, which 3 cups is 24 OZ.  A can comes in 14 OZ.  So that's 1.71 cans.   I ended up putting two 14 OZ cans.   I have to say it was WAY too sweet and rich for my liking.   I'm gonna find a lighter recipe.  I think anything over 1 can is too much sugar.   ***However is was extremely easy to make this***

text:
This is great. I have made this several times. I bring it to every summer bbq I attend. Here's the thing: key limes are VERY variable in the amount of juice they yield and in tartness so you need 1-2 lbs of limes and you must taste the filling as you make it. I start with 2 cans of condensed milk. If it's too tart I open up the second can and add to taste.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie is awesome! I also used two can of condensed milk and discovered an easy way to squeeze your limes. Roll them between your hand and the counter until they are soft. Don't be afraid to put a lot of pressure on them. The softer they are the easier it is to squeeze them. Cut them in half (not through the stem). Hold a half in your palm and use a fork to scrape the inside of the lime. The juice (and the delicious pulp) just pours right out! I found that I won't need nearly as many limes when I use this method. Delicious pie! I won't be using another recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/627948.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good with a few slight modifications:
-I made a homemade graham cracker crust, which is really simple and elevates the taste so much.  I used "Graham Cracker Crust" from this website.
-I used bottled key lime juice, as my local store did not sell key limes (and I'm too impatient to spend that much time juicing limes!).  Because of this, I also omitted the zest.  I'm not sure if this juice is a little extra potent or not, but next time, I will cut back ever-so-slightly on the amount of lime juice I use, as it was a little overpowering.
-I kept my pie in the oven for 11 minutes and it never bubbled.  It doesn't seem to have caused too much trouble though, as it has a nice firm texture after sitting in the refrigerator overnight.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie was fabulous!  It was so easy, too.  I've never cared for key lime pie but this one was so creamy and just sweet enough.  I think the addition of the sour cream gives it such a nice light texture and smoothes out the acidity in the limes some.  I used two full cans of the sweetened condensed milk, full fat sour cream and juice from those little Mexican limes.  I also squeezed one drop of green food coloring in it for a lovely pale green.  This will be perfect for Easter dessert.  Thanks for sharing this!
01/09/15 update!  I just discovered that there is an English dessert called Posset, which is a now a type of citrus pudding that is very similar to this filling recipe.  It uses sugar and heavy cream (double cream in England) instead of the condensed milk.  The principal is the same, the lemon/lime juice helps coagulate the cream so it firms up.  Very interesting!  I'd never heard of Posset before.  Just thought I'd share!

Fantastic - couldn't be easier to make & tastes perfect.

I used the recipe to make 6 mini pies in my jumbo muffin tin.  I used graham cracker crumbs to do the crusts (followed the recipe on the box for 1 pie crust).  I would have been better off making 8 mini's instead of six, though, as I had leftover filling and the crusts were quite thick.  Also had to bake for almost 20 minutes, 5-8 definitely was not long enough.

text:
Superb recipe!  I doubled the filling ingredients, because I was putting the pie in a 10-inch deep-dish.  I made my own graham cracker crust (doubled the usual 9-inch crust recipe for that, too) and pre-baked the crust for about 12 minutes.  Had some leftover graham cracker crust, so I placed it into small pudding ramekin bowls, with the intention to make a quick pudding dessert with it, but then I had just a 3/4 cup of filling that didn't fit in the pie dish, so I put the filling leftovers into one of the ramekin cups with a crust, and baked that for 8 minutes.  Needless to say, I could try out the pie before the large pie was done, thanks to this little sampler I created!  It's awesome!  Makes a great Packer Superbowl pie for today's football party, along with a bright yellow lemon meringue pie.  Go, Pack, Go!

text:
I hate key lime pie, but it's my dad's favorite. Made it for a party for him and everyone said it was delicious! I followed it exactly though and it made too much. (And what makes no sense to me is 3 cups= 24 oz. yet, 2 14 oz. cans of milk measured out only to 1 2/3 cups?) So I bought 3 cans so I had enough and measured out 3 cups of the milk exactly. I probably should have listened to the comments about just using to cans because I ended up with too much filling and don't know what to do with it! Not enough for another pie. Also, the squeezing the key limes was PAINSTAKING. It's also cheaper to buy an equally good pie at the store (which is unusual for homemade food, I think.) Wish they made pre-squeezed key lime juice like they have regular lime juice! :( Good recipe none the less!

text:
Living in Arizona with a newly planted Mexican Lime tree full of fruit, I sought recipes using fresh limes to utilize the fruit that outnumbered our need from Mexican beer.  There it was "key Lime Pie VII".  As a desert after an evening of grilled delights, it was met with rave reviews.  I lacked the time for the homemade crust, but no one seemed to dampen their consumption as their forks scrapped the plates clean enough to return to the cabinets.  The fruit was  picked, pressed and pied within an hour.  It did take a lot of thumb exercise to squeeze the 3/4 cup of juice and like other reviewers, I used 2 cans of condensed milk.  Topping it off with fresh whipped cream had my daughters boyfriend rating it "amazing.". Thank you Ann for the recipe that will be used as often as our Mexican Lime tree bears fruit.

text:
This was so easy and delicious!  I can't get key limes or key lime juice where I live, so just used regular limes and store bought lime juice.  I just added a little extra lime juice because it wasn't quite tart enough.  I think I'll add a little extra zest next time, but it does gets tarter over time.  I used two cans of sweetened condensed milk as others have recommended.  I baked it for only 10 minutes even though I didn't really see any tiny bubbles.  I refrigerated it over night and it set up great.  So creamy!  I topped it with Cool Whip which was a nice contrast to the tart.

text:
I used this recipe for my first attempt at making a key lime pie for a Fourth of July party.  It was so easy to make and the taste and texture were perfect!  I also used a springform pan and let the pie chill overnight.  When released, it made for a beautiful presentation!  (Just make sure you spray the pan with non-stick coating before pressing the graham cracker crust in.  In addition, I baked the crust for five minutes at 350 before adding the filling.) After letting the pie chill thoroughly, I piped freshly made sweetened whipped cream on top and garnished with a lime wedge.  You will not be disappointed with this recipe!

text:
I think this is the best recipe on Allrecipes.com. It is easy, quick, and fabulous. I love that it has no eggs, but sets up perfectly. When I first read it, I thought liquidy ingrediant, liquidy ingrediant, and liquidy ingrediant= soup. But the acid in the lime juice sets off a wonderful chemical reaction and the results are smooth, creamy and wonderful. It's sets up right away- the texture when it is hot ouf the oven is the same as it will be after cooling. I've never had one weep or turn out soft. Try this recipe, you won't regret it.

text:
This was so much better than I thought it might  be! Seemed like a  lot of lime juice, but ended up being the right ratio.  Instead of juicing limes, I used store-bought bottled key-lime juice.  I also used 2 cans (14 oz.) of condensed milk - with a store-bought extra large graham crust, the filling amount was perfect.  Baked for 13 minutes.  Chilled in freezer an hour before serving.  A delicious Summer recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have a very picky college kid who developed a love for Key Lime Pie after our family vacation, but no matter how many different ones we've tried, none met her standards until now.  I can't believe how easily this went together.  I got a 10 inch premade pie crust (instead of 9 inch) and increased quantities of all the ingredients just slightly with no problems.  We used bottled Mexican lime juice and it was way easier than juicing all those limes would have been.   Like several others have mentioned, during baking, it's hard to tell when those tiny bubbles show up - I didn't really see them - so I left it in the oven for about 10 minutes or so.  As long as it doesn't brown, it's fine.  I'm sure we'll be making this again, and may try topping it with meringue next time.  When you need a quick, super easy desert that is sure to please, this is perfect.

text:
I LOVE key lime pie and I've made several key lime pie recipes from this site. This one is my favorite! I've made this one a few different times and I am always pleased with the turnout. I have made Key Lime Pie IX, and although it is also delicious, it is a bit too heavy because of the added egg yolks. This recipe does not call for any eggs and doesn't need it! I've also made this recipe with light sour cream and low fat sweetened condensed milk and it is still just as delicious. This pie is great because it takes no time at all to throw it together and bake. Everyone loves it!

text:
I only gave 4 stars b/c I thought this was too tart but I have not tried a lot of key lime pies. Other than that, the recipe was perfect--very easy and perfect texture. Paired with some cool whip/whip cream it totally softened the taste. Someone suggested my key limes may have been not ripe enough (too bitter). The flavors seemed to settle more the day after so it wasn't quite so tart. I may try the lemon/lime combo next time that others used and will definitely use the bottled juice since many reviews said they didn't notice a difference.  I interpereted 3 cups of SCM to equal 24oz.--isn't that correct? I barely baked it and it was firm (maybe 5-8 minutes)it must be some type of chemical reaction btw all of the ingredients that firms it..served frozen. Very Good.

country:
None
text:
Such an easy and freakin delicious recipe!  Feel in love with it in summer 2009 and made two that summer.  I do have a couple recommendations/suggestions: 1) there is no taste difference between regular and fat free sweetened condensed milk. 2) 3/4 cup key lime juice is equivalent to Hot salsa     2/3 cup is equivalent to Medium salsa     1/2 cup is equivalent to Mild salsa 3) 3/4 cup sour cream will make it creamier, but will overfill the pie crust a little.   4) 10 mins max in the oven. 5) Use electric mixer to combine the ingredients, helps add air and fluffiness.  Other than that, its a rock solid, fool proof recipe AAA+ my friend

text:
Perfect.  Liked other reviewer's suggestion of using garlic press to juice halved key limes. Also homemade crust is a must: 1 1/2 C finely crushed graham cracker crumbs, 6 T melted butter, 6 T sugar.  Stir together, press on bottom and sides of pie plate firmly and bake @ 350 for 7 min.  Cool in fridge while making key lime filling.

text:
I made this for Easter dinner on Sunday.  This recipe is not only yummy but very quick and simple.  The longest thing about it is squeezing the key limes.  I used a metal mesh strainer over a glass measuring cup.  That way the seeds and pulp didn't get into the juice and I could use it as a press to work as much of the juice out as possible.  It took about 20 key limes for me as well.

Quick and easy.  I subbed bottled lime juice for key lime juice (couldn't find it at my store).  The pinholes appeared after about 9 minutes, but very tiny!  Don't expect "bursting" just look for little dots.  Aside from the slightly different lime flavor due to the substitution, flavor was great and the sour cream gave it a less custard-y, more creamy texture than one made with eggs.

text:
Absolutely flawless and too delicious for such a easy recipe. At first I found it to be too sour and sweet when eaten by itself, then I added a bit whip cream and voila, the perfect mix of creaminess, texture, tanginess and sweetness. I am making another one to take to girlfriend's house. I did substitute 1/4 cup of Persian lime juice for the key lime juice because quite frankly one bag of key limes from Publix barely yielded me 1/2 cup of key lime juice. Supposedly if one mixes half lemon juice and half lime juice, the flavor profile can be very close to one made with real key lime juice, will try that when I have a chance. Key lime is way too expensive where I am from (like $3 for one-lb bag).

text:
You really wouldn't think these ingredients would "bake" into a sliceable pie- BUT THEY DO! I made 2 pies at the same time. One with REAL Key lime juice (my thumbs hurt so much after that squeezing because I couldnt find the bottled key lime juice) and one with "regular" bottled lime juice. Both made beautiful and yummy pies that everyone at work loved, but the difference in the taste of the pies was significant enough that I would spend the extra time squeezing the real key limes. The taste of that pie was just that much yummier, although the other one still tasted good.  I had 5 colleagues ask for the recipe. With how simple it was, I almost didnt want to tell them!

text:
Love this recipe!!  I used 3 persian limes (the only kind available at my grocery store), zested and juiced them, then used Nellie and Joe's Key West Lime Juice to equal 3/4 Cup.  I used 2 cans of fat free sweetened condensed milk and 1/2 C. fat free sour cream.  I baked it for about 10 minutes and it came out perfectly.  I will definitely make this again and again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I had to come back and write a review on this. Make it. Don't change a thing.  I live in Palm Springs, CA and we have 2 wild Mexican lime trees in the back yard. Wow...   they are in season now, and I used them for this.  Very Easy to make. I followed the recipe exactly and used those Keebler graham cracker crusts on the store shelves which are not refrigerated. I beet and egg and  brushed the crust with the egg wash, then backed the crust for 8 min in a 375 oven. Cooled the crust, then added the batter, and baked the pie for 8 min more. I used Cool Whip dolloped on top after it chilled in the fridge for 3 hours...  Wow... Thanks! The perfect desert!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1040985.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, if you're looking for a creamy, rich key lime pie (that would be me)! :)  It almost has the consistency of a cheesecake, and I had several people ask if it contained cheese.  I used this recipe to make a dozen mini pies in my cupcake pan, and therefore made a homemade graham cracker crust (Graham Cracker Crust II on this site, is an excellent pair up)!  For "mini pies", I baked for 15 minutes at 350 F (or even 325 - my oven runs hotter than it states).  I had a slight problem removing them from the cupcake pan (even after chilling overnight), but that is no fault of this recipe.  I should have pre-baked the crust to harden more, and I should have also used paper liners.  This is such a simple recipe (albeit, juicing the limes is a bit painful), it's worth it. :)  I used regular limes, and only had enough to make 1/2 cup, so made sure to zest all 4 limes I had.  Great, strong lime flavor.  Easy peasy!

text:
This pie is amazing, and so simple.  I did as other reviewers did and used 2 14-oz cans of sweetened condensed milk.  I used the amount of lime juice called for and thought it was perfect, I did hand squeeze key limes - it took a while but I don't think it would be quite right with bottled lime juice.  My only complaint about the recipe is the cook time, it really took more like 10-15 minutes to get the pinholes.

This might be the best Key Lime pie I've ever made, and I've made A LOT!   I used some key lime juice I got on a recent trip to Key West, FL which made it SO easy! (I used regular lime zest). Three cups of sweetened condensed milk is 2 2/3 cans, if anyone is wondering.  I saw the bubbles forming after 10 minutes in the oven -- they are easy to see if you look for their reflection against the light.  This was definitely a great pie.

helpfulCount:

userID:
1027007
Display Name:
Sarah Dipity
isPro:
False
followersCount:
280
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
213
favoritesCount:
867
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/347683.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So easy!  I used 2 (14 oz) cans of sweetened condensed milk, 3/4 cup regular lime juice, and baked it for 13 minutes.  I never did see any bubbles form on the surface.  Topped it with homemade whipped cream.  It had the consistency of a creme brulee (minus the crusty top).  YUM!  Next time I'll try the lower fat/calorie ingredient options.  p.s. I wish I understood the science behind this recipe.  It's just so amazing to me that it bakes up nice and firm with only liquid ingredients and no eggs.  I've also made this into mini pies with the pre-made mini pie shells (fills 14 shells).  I made the graham cracker crust by pulsing 12 graham cracker (sheets), 5 Tbls melted butter, 1/4 cup sugar, and 1/8 tsp salt into a fine sand. I made homemade whipped cream with 2 1/2 cups heavy whipping cream, 2 1/2 teaspoons vanilla, and 3 Tbls powdered sugar and pipped a rose pattern over the entire pie. SO GOOD!! UPDATE: the grocery store was out of regular graham crackers so I bought a box of already crushed crackers. I used 1 1/2 cups, 1/4 cup sugar, 1/8 tsp salt and 7 tablespoons butter.

This pie was WONDERFUL! I grew up in Florida and have been looking for a recipe that tasted just like I remember it.....AND I DID....but I almost think this one is better!!!! It is so easy that the first time it came out perfect! No do overs here LOL! My Fiance' was born and raised in Tennessee (home of southern cooking) and he thinks this is the best pie he has ever tasted! I did use some of the hints like the 3 cups of sweetened condensed milk = 2 14 oz cans and if you use the real limes (instead of bottled juice)it's approx. 20 (that came in handy when shopping)But other than that the recipe is flawless! DON'T CHANGE A THING!! Thank you so much Ann for this delicious recipe!

text:
Over the years, my family has spent a lot of time in Florida.  I have tried a few Key Lime Pie recipes but could never achieve a result like a really good restaurant pie.  Well, here it is!  The zest makes the difference so don't leave it out.(I used the zest from one regular lime).  Others have complained about the juicing of the limes....you should be able to find bottled key lime juice in the juice isle at the grocery.  I live in the sticks and we have it here!  Also, the fact that there are no egg yolks involved gives it a much cleaner flavor.  Texture is unbelievably creamy.  I prepared with home made graham cracker crust and real whipped cream...AMAZING

text:
This pie is fabulous!! The suggestion by one reviewer to use a garlic press, is not only smart, but also very thoughtful to pass that on! With my little rectangle press, I first put the half lime in sideways and pressed slightly, then flipped it pulp side down. I got the maximum juice from my key limes. I made 2 pies and used 40 little limes to make the 1 1/2 cups needed. This is now a "must" pie for all family gatherings!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
OK... I have never written a review before. But, I felt the need to write one for this recipe because I almost didn't make it. This would have been a mistake because it is WONDERFUL! The reason I almost didn't make it was because I thought there was a mistake in the recipe. I kept reading the ingredients over and over wondering if the egg yolks had been left out. I couldn't understand what would make the filling "set". Sour cream, lime juice and condensed milk are very runny ingredients and there was no "binding" ingredient. Boy was I wrong. When the lime juice is added to the ingredients it creates a reaction and almost intantly thinkens the filling and baking it completely sets it.You can actaully serve the filling without baking. I actually served my hubby some leftover filling (that didn't fit into the pie crust)in a martini glass garnished with some graham cracker sticks and some fresh whipped cream. Since it doesn't have any egg in it, it was perfectly safe to eat. Very quick and YUMMY!

country:
None
text:
I was never a big fan of key lime pie, because of the tartness, but it is my mother-in-law's fav pie. I made this for her birthday, followed faithfully on recipe. The hardest part was squeezing the juice out from the tiny key limes (about 22)even though I used a garlic presser to help. Not to mention getting the zest out first was a big pain. I couldn't fulfill the required quantity, just shy of some because my fingers were so sore from grating the tiny fruit. Everything else after that was a walk in the par. My pie didn't turned out white like the image shown, becuase of the color of my condensed milk which was yellow. I wanted to make a double batch since I bought 2 cookie pie crusts, but with the tedious retrieving lime juice part, I stuck to making only 1. I didn't get to taste it because I gave it away as a present. My mother in law who just turn 78, told me that it is the best key lime pie she has ever tasted! She gave me a piece, and Boy! it was FANTASTIC! I might make it again if I forget how hard it was to squeeze those limes!

text:
This pie is delicious!! I have made this twice within the last couple of weeks for family and friends, and they loved it. Key lime pie is my favorite dessert, and I couldn't believe how easy it is to make. I made a few changes to make it lower fat.  I used 1 can of regular sweetened condensed milk and 1 can of fat free. I used low fat sour cream and a low fat pre-made crust.  I cheated and used pre-squeezed lime juice, and also left off the lime zest. I baked it for 12 minutes. It was perfect. This recipe is a keeper!

text:
This was easy and super delicious! It tasted just as good as any I've gotten in restaurants. I served mine with a raspberry sauce (1 10-oz package of frozen raspberries, thawed, then run through a food processor until pureed) and used a store-bought graham cracker crust. You could buy Key Lime juice in the grocery store, usually near regular lemon juice so there's no need to squeeze those little limes! I will definately be making this one again.

It won't separate because the whey has been removed.

text:
With more than 150 outstanding ratings, this recipe doesn't really need another positive review, but I was so blown away by the ease and taste that I had to add my own endorsement. As with others, I never could actually see small bubbles on the top, so I took it out of the oven after about 13 minutes. The texture was perfect. I had been looking for a reliable key lime pie recipe, and this is it!!! No need for further searching! This is now my first choice for dessert when I'm hosting dinners at my house.

Can't say that I've ever had Key Lime Pie but hub was rattling on about how good it was for years.  Told him to look out for the limes and bring them home.  Well, I am SO glad that he finally found some where we live. Just the right sweetness to tartness.  There was just enough left for us to have a taste of such perfection.  Thanks for a classic keeper!

Baked 8 minutes (no bubbling like the recipe indicated) and threw it in the freezer because I couldn't wait for it to cool and have a bite! It holds up very well and tastes perfect!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
A great recipe! I didn't follow the recipe exactly, though, because for something like key lime pie, you need to make it as sweet or as sour as reflects your preference. I added a little bit of lemon juice, splash of vanilla, and heavy whipping cream to my filling. I highly recommend making a homemade graham cracker crust, which I did, and I added a pinch of cinnamon to my crust as well. After the pie was out of the oven, I added an even sprinkling of crushed graham cracker crumbs, lime zest, and a twisted lime for decoration in the center. I served with homemade whipped cream on the side. The result was fantastic. Everyone raved about the pie and one key lime fan said it was the best she'd ever had. A great recipe, but remember to change it if you think it's too sweet or too sour as is - everyone has their preference.

text:
This pie was superb, just what I wanted. As someone else said, it isn't very sweet - it lets all the key lime goodness come through. Perfect for a summer dessert.

The only modification I made was to add one egg yolk into the mix. I had seen it in other recipes, and wanted to make sure it set up good.

It set up perfectly, able to hold its own but still nice and creamy. Good with a little whipped cream to give you an alternate flavour from the sharp, delish lime.

I know it's a lot of work squeezing those limes (had to do 40 for 2 pies), but it's well worth it for this. text:
I prefer the dense creaminess of this kind of key lime pie over those that are all fluff.  However, all the sweetened condensed milk was a bit overpowering & sugary.  It was hard to enjoy the lime taste.  I also liked that there was no gelatin or food coloring added.  But I'm going to try Key Lime Pie VIII next time as it has a mixture of the milk and whipping cream.  If you're looking for a crust, I made Graham Cracker Crust II.  It doesn't require sugar so it goes well with this pie recipe, which definitely doesn't need more sweetness!

userID:
12931787
Display Name:
Jessica St.Thomas
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6294758.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When doing cupcake size, make crust from 1 1/2 sleeves graham crackers, about 1/3 cup walnuts and about 1/4 teas cinnamon. Process well. Add about 6 Tbs melted butter while running food processor. Put 1  and 1/2 Tbs crust into bottom of cupcake wrapper. Press down with 1/4 cup measure. Use larger scoop (standard cupcake) to fill to near top. May need to add a bit more. Bake at 350 for 4 minutes, turn then 3 minutes more. Cool in cupcake tin for at least 10 minutes then remove to wire rack. Cool on counter for at least 15 minutes then move to fridge. Makes 16-17

text:
I made this pie exactly as was instructed, and it was indeed as easy as it sounds. My only complaint is that it was WAY too limey. 3/4 cup of fresh lime juice made it so tart I could hardly eat it. Some of the people who ate it said it was tasty while others agreed with me that it was too strong. I love how easy this was to make, and the pie consistency was excellent, but if I make it again I'm going to use about half of the recommended lime juice and see how that turns out.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7605559.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is by far the most delicious, the easiest and the most authentic-tasting Key Lime Pie I’ve ever made. And I love Key Lime Pie. I’ve made it at least a dozen times and I always get rave reviews. I didn’t change the recipe at all... the only thing I did differently is that I made my own graham cracker crust (use one of the three graham cracker packages that comes in a box of three, crushed very fine in a food processor or put in a zip-lock bag and crushed with a rolling pin, mixed with 3 tablespoons melted butter and 3 tablespoons sugar then pressed into the bottom of a 9” springform pan). When the pie is cooled, remove the springform ring and keep it in the freezer. I like it more firm and chilled. Perfect. ??

None
text:
This was delicious with the right tart flavor. The 3 cups of condensed milk was confusing. A can of sweetened condensed milk is 14 ounce net weight and equal to 8 fluid ounces. I used two 14 ounce cans and it was more than enough for my pie shell. My pie also never bubbled, so I kept leaving it in the oven and it cooked for 20 minutes. It never browned and was perfectly fine and somewhat light.

Display Name:
Ginny Litzelfelner
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6340664.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will definitely make this Key Lime pie again. How can something so easy  be so yummy? All i can say is...it is! Our grocer has a sale on limes this week: 3 for $0.99. and even though the sign said “large limes” they are actually somewhere between the size of a Key lime and a regular one. Seven limes rendered the necessary 3/4 cup juice. Note to self: buy the larger size graham cracker ready-made crust because this recipe filled 1-1/2 regular sized pie shells. I’m glad I read several reviews because I altered the time in the oven to about 15 minutes and never did see any tiny bubbles surfacing but I did notice the edges becoming the palest shade of brown so I pulled it out. After cooling for 3 hours it was perfectly set and ready to enjoy. Even my husband who views himself as a Key Lime Pie aficionado raved about it. Cool, silky, limey tart and sweet accompanied by the crisp, buttery goodness of the graham cracker crust!

My husband and daughter absolutely love it!  The only change I made was making my own graham cracker crust instead of using a store bought one.

text:
My boyfriend and his adult son said it was better than the one they had in Key West. I used 3 medium-sized limes for zest, the juice of the fresh limes, and supplemented with bottled key lime juice. I used a 10-inch store-bought crust, and this recipe filled the crust with just enough room for piped whipped cream. You need three cans of condensed milk; I'm glad I had an extra can in the cupboard. Even I liked it and I'm not a fan of Key Lime Pie.

text:
I am not a fan of lime in general so this review is based off of my husband and daughter. From an easy standpoint this recipe was ridiculously easy. Minimal ingredients and minimal work goes into this simple and delicious recipe. I ate one bite, they each had a slice. I cheated and used key west lime juice in a bottle, I know it isn’t the same as fresh but it wasn’t cost effective to buy limes. It ended up baking for 8 mins to get the pin holes. I let it cool for a bit before I put in fridge to get cold for after dinner. It came out in the pie shape after cutting it. I would make again for the ease of prep work. I personally am not a fan of lines. Otherwise it definitely deserves its 5/5 stars.

text:
I have made this several times and everyone loved it. Each time I've been told by at least one person that it is the best key lime pie they have ever had. I made the crust using Keebler Graham Cracker Crumbs, and followed the recipe that came on the box. (I have used both key limes and regular limes on separate occasions, and in my opinion the regular limes yielded a better result. About 4-6 regular limes should give you 3/4 cup of lime juice when using a lime juicer.) STRONGLY RECOMMEND

text:
I'm new to making pies, I absolutely love Key Lime pie and gave this recipe a shot.  WOW just WOW this is by far the best Key Lime pie I've had.  I didn't change anything to the recipe and it turned out perfect.  I made my own graham cracker crust to boot.  
My local store sold Key Lime juice $2 for 16oz so I went that route.  I did zest a good tbs of lime for the pie.  My girlfriend recommended an N2O whipped cream dispenser versus making whipped cream by hand.  My parents stopped by to drop off some items and helped finish off the pie.  I couldn't believe how easy this was to make.  

I'm going to make several of these for our company party next week.

Huge thumbs up.

None
text:
I made this for Eid dinner with a gluten free premade crust. I couldn't find key limes so I used about 10 fresh limes and the rest in lime concentrate. I tasted the batter and added more lime juice till I got the flavor I wanted. 

I had my doubts at first as I had some leftover batter and put them in mini cupcake liners and baked it and the taste and texture was AWFUL! I was ready to throw it all out.

However I left the pie to rest in the fridge for a day and it was divine! My guests also really liked it.

text:
I made this with the crust from Phoenician’s key lime recipe.  It was amazing!  I doubled the recipe and made it in a 13x9 glass baking dish.  The crust is pretty thick, so I may try 1.5 times the crust recipe next time. I used 4 cans of SCM, which is less than the recipe calls for, but it was still great.  I used bottled lime juice.  Once it cooled off, I covered it with a thin layer of whipping cream.  We had a little dessert bake off at work with about 20 different desserts, and this one won first place!

I can’t wait to make this again with the correct ratios: it’s sure to be phenomenal! Thank you for sharing!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night for pi day along with a blackberry pie, and I'm glad I did.  I followed the recipe as closely as possible as it was my first attempt.  Used 2 cans sweetened condensed milk, a store-bought graham cracker crust, and used the key lime juice found at the store.  Took 5 minutes to prepare, if that.   Baked in the oven 10 minutes before taking it out.  No bubbles, so I focused on the jiggle only.  After setting in the fridge overnight, I served it with whipped topping and it was a major hit.  One person even said it was the best key lime pie they've ever tasted.  It's so easy that you should at LEAST try it.

text:
Substituted evaporated milk (unsweetened) and 1/3 c. sugar for the condensed milk. I used regular limes and a little lemon juice (when I got tired of squeezing limes), didn't bother with the zest, and it was still very tasty--and very easy except for squeezing the limes. The recipe seemed to make more filling than fit in the crust I had (9" graham cracker, as called for). I just ate the remainder like pudding...The pie didn't quite set but I assume that's because I mistakenly had the oven at 325 instead of 350 (I turned it up, but presumably too late).

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a terrible recipe. It's not even close to authentic and those are Persian limes in the photo.  Here's the authentic recipe from my great-great grandmother's Florida Keys diner:
1 can sweetened condensed milk
4  egg yolks
1/2 cup KEY LIME juice, bottled or fresh
Scrape the milk out of the can into a bowl. Beat in the yolks then add the juice with beaters running.  Scrape into graham cracker crust.  Either bake for 15 mins at 350 and chill till serving time or refrigerate for 8 hours if you dont worry about eating raw eggs. No topping or meringue on an authentic pie.

text:
I made this for work and everyone loved it. They called it the best Key Lime Pie they’d ever had. Everyone wanted the recipe. I had a slice left that I brought home for my family and they loved it too. My 10 year old son just helped me make one for Christmas dinner tomorrow because he said it was good enough to have year round. I would agree. I didn’t have real limes so no zest in my recipe. I used the bottle of key lime juice which I found I. The juice aisle. I mixed together a little sour cream, confectioners sugar and a drop of rum extract for the topping (because rum goes great with key lime pie!) This recipe is staying in he dessert rotation at my house. It was quick, easy and impressive.

text:
This pie is a huge hit and family favorite! The zest added makes all the difference. It can sometimes be a challenge to find keylimes but they can’t be substituted for anything else if you want that authentic key lime pie! I typically buy two bags of key limes for on each pie as I usually need about 3 extra keylimes to get the full 3/4 cup of key lime juice and the 1tbsp of zest. I do bake about twice as long and check every couple of minutes for the tiny pinhole bubbles to form.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe last week and it was a hit.  I was unsure of the 2 full cans of sweetened condensed milk but didn't know what I'd do with the leftover so I added both.
Very, very creamy, easy to make, but a little sweet.  Next time I will increase the lime just a bit to account for the sweetness.
I used 5 limes and the rinds from one.  Think I'll use 5.5-6 limes next time and taste as I go.  

I noticed many folks complaining about the difficulty of limes.  Here's a trick.

1.  Put 2-3 in the microwave for 10-15 seconds
2.  Take them out and roll them on counter and don't forget to roll them from top to bottom as well.
3.  Then, cut 4 heavy strips from the "core of the lemon/lime, and from each of those, squeeze.  
MUCH easier!

text:
Made this for my Mom’s birthday, and it turned out delicious. I bought the bottled key lime juice, as others mentioned. I’ve juiced key limes before, and it’s a bit of a pain, so I was happy to read about a great alternative. I used a graham cracker crust recipe from this site (graham cracker crust II) as well. I had a little bit of crust and a little bit of pie filling left over, so I layered crust and filling in a couple of one cup bowls, and my son and I had a little key lime “pudding”...it was a delicious preview of the finished pie! No eggs in the recipe so it’s safe to eat before baking! Will definitely make it again. My sister took one bite and said, “wow! This is REALLY good!” I said, “well of course it is! I made it!” ??

Display Name:
Angelique Hosang
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6449921.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Who knew you DIDN'T need eggs to make key lime pie??!!  But it's true.  This is my favorite out of 3 other key lime pie recipes I tried from this site.  I used 2 (14 oz) cans of sweetened condensed milk and it was the perfect amount. 
 Also, 3/4 cup Nellie & Joe's bottled key lime juice gave it the perfect amount of lime flavor.  I put my oven light on and saw the little pin-hole bubbles after 8 minutes. Don't mess with this recipe.  It comes out great if you follow it just as is.   I made my own crust with 1 1/2 cup graham cracker crumbs plus a little over 1/2 cup of vegan butter spread and baked at 350 for 8 minutes (could've been a little longer for more crunch).  This pie won't last one day in my house.  Everyone loves it!

text:
Since I didn't have key lime I used 2 regular limes and 1 large lemon which came out to exactly 3/4.  (I had read that equal parts of regular limes and lemons can be substituted for key limes). Two can of the sweetened condensed milk makes it sweet enough. It came out so delicious and full of flavor. The tiny bubbles never formed so I took it out after 10 minutes and it was perfect. I like this recipe because I do not like the taste of the eggs in the other recipes. I will make this again as it was so easy to make and was a hit with my dinner guests!

This was delicious - my whole extended family loved it. I'll make it again, but with a slight change. Next time I'll use 1/3C sour cream instead of 1/2C. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie was AWESOME and super quick to make!  Given that limes in the Seattle area cost $1.00 ea and I couldn't afford to spend $20 on 20 limes, I did substitute using Nellie & Joe's Key Lime juice and added the zest from one lime.  I also made my own graham cracker crust which I baked for 10min and then cooled before adding the pie filling.  My oven is old, so I baked the pie for approx 12min - the "bubbles" looked like pin pricks, but when they surfaced is when I removed the pie from the oven - it was set perfect!  I let it cool and refrigerated it for about 2 hours during our family dinner... it sliced up beautifully and everyone LOVED it!  Thank you for the recipe!

text:
I made this for my son last night  and chilled it in the fridge over night. We tried it this morning and it was out of this world AMAZING! ****Just a heads up to anyone making it.**** It takes (roughly) about 35-40 key limes to make so make sure you have enough. I also used a garlic press to squeeze the limes and cut those in fours so they would fit. If you don’t own one already, BUY ONE because it helps big time! I also topped this with Cool Whip and sliced key limes. This was my first time making a key lime pie and I will DEFINITELY be making this again!

None
text:
Excellent!  I used a homemade graham cracker crust and made cupcake size pies, using parchment paper cupcake liners.  I put 1 Tablespoon of graham cracker crust in each one and patted it down, then baked it until golden brown.  I cooled them slightly then added the key lime pie mixture and baked it at 325 degrees in my convection oven for 7 minutes.  They turned out perfect!

text:
Easy and Delicious! I followed recipe exactly as written, (I used Nellie and Joe's Key West Key Lime Juice) though I chose not to put lime zest in the filling as I don't really care for the look or green strings in it. Pretty enough atop if desired. I top mine with a layer of freshly whipped cream. (a pint whipped with a little sugar and vanilla does 2 topping layers) It is very sweet as expected so slim I feel it goes far due to slim slices being enough. It cuts beautifully. I would like to find a key lime recipe that doesn't rely upon sweetened condensed milk but there is no guarantee I'd like it better.

text:
Best key lime pie I've ever had!!! I followed the recipe exactly EXCEPT I didn't have key limes so I used regular limes (gasp!!). I was nervous about this, but I read that Ree Drummond has used regular lime juice in a key lime pie before so I figured it couldn't be all that bad. Well, it was fabulous... I couldn't tell the difference at all and my husband RAVED about it!!! And bonus,  regular limes don't take as long to squeeze since they're larger. I think I used 8 limes. Be sure to add the zest, it really adds that extra little zing! Planning to make this again in a couple of weeks for the 4th!!

Nice and tart.  I cheated with a store bought crust, ooh don't tell anyone.  Didn't have time for a homemade crust which would have made this review a six.  Our zest was nice and small.  This made the addition of the lime almost unnoticeable.  We had a $22 key lime pie down in the keys December of 2017 and this was just as good.  Made my own whipped topping using heavy whipping cream.  Took all but a couple minutes to make and add.  We took it to a Memorial Day cookout and other Key Lime Pie aficionados loved it as well.  Great recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie was awesome. I had started out looking for a key lime pie recipe and mistakenly prepped the 4 egg yolks called for in another recipe so I included those.  I used 2 14-oz cans, plus 1 7-oz can of sweetened condensed milk to equal 3 cups.  I mixed the SCM with the egg yolks, then tempered in 3/4 C lime juice and added the lime zest.  It took about 10 key limes to get the zest needed. Unfortunately, I had a spill during the process so added some bottled key lime juice to make up for that loss.  I put the ingredients in a Keebler graham cracker crust that said it makes 2 extra servings - it fit well, about 1/4" from the top of the crust. I cooked it for 15 minutes and chilled the pie as indicated . . . it was really good.  I didn't put on the whipping cream yet, but I may when I serve it to guests tomorrow.  That part can be their choice.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this recipe two ways - one using fresh squeezed key limes for juice and the other using bottled key lime juice.  The obvious difference (picture of pies side-by-side) is that Pie 1 made with fresh key limes is lighter in color,  where Pie 2 made with bottled juice looks darker. Pie 1 was more tart and had a better flavor. Pie 2 was not bad and, without the comparison, probably would not be able to tell the difference.  Followed the recipe exactly but baked almost 14 minutes and still no bubbles. Both options taste good, so it just depends on if you want to take the time to squeeze all those tiny key limes. I will probably squeeze them again when I make the next one!

userID:
9269246
Display Name:
Kels1232
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
136
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5814468.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a date who had told me prior that key lime was his favorite. I was a little nervous but after reading the reviews, I took a leap of faith...so glad I did! I used a about a cup of key lime juice (for me 3/4 cup didn’t really give it the lime taste I wanted & the condensed milk over powered it) I hand squeezed them using a lime squeezer I found at Walmart. It went pretty fast. I baked it for 10 mins after reading the other reviews, let it cool on the counter a bit and then refrigerated for 4 hours before serving. It was a hit & he couldn’t stop raving about it. I used a flour sifter to strain the freshly squeezed juice to make sure there were no hidden seeds, etc. The fresh key lime zest made it even better! The pic is when it was still warm but before serving I garnished with whip cream & key lime twists. Love this!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
Tastes great! Fast and easy to make. Mine didn't have bubbles so I baked it a bit longer, but still none, I guess it doesn't always do that.

I added shredded coconut to it as well. The one in the photo is a test one with a premade crust. When I make a second one I'll be using a Graham cracker crust with coconut oil subbed for the butter.

Oh also a note: this recipe makes more filling than will fit in a crust, so you'll be able to make 1.5-2 pies.

A few notes from my experience - Two 14 oz. cans of condensed milk do not yield 3 measured cups....probably has something to do with how the ounces are measured (weight, mass...clearly I missed this in science class).  Because of this, the filling was slightly low in the crust.  However,it was not a big deal.  I used just the two cans and the filling was delicious.  I also made homemade whipped ream. Great pie!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ahh-Mazing!!! Just like others, I received rave reviews with this recipe. I made my own crust, here’s the recipe for wonderful homemade graham cracker crust... 1 ¼ cups graham cracker crumbs, 1/2 cup pecans finely chopped, 1/4 cup sugar, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 cup melted butter. Cook crust for 8 minutes and let it cool while juicing the limes. I used just a tad less than 3/4 cups lime juice. The other thing I did was I left the pie in the oven after cooking with door slightly open for 30 minutes as another reviewer had suggested prior to putting in the refrigerator. I even used a spring foam pan and it held together wonderfully!!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4529933.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This ranks a 10 out of 10!!!!  Use 2 14-oz. cans sweetened condensed milk. (Measures appx. 2.5 cups, but this amt works well and doesn't overfill the pie crust.)  1 lime gives about 1 T. of needed zest. Buy an extra lime if you want to slice thinly and/or zest for decor on top. (Tip: Use a good garlic press to juice keylimes.) Place prepped pie with filling on large pan and bake 10-11 minutes, watching so it doesn't brown. Cool thoroughly (in fridge) then "frost" with homemade whipped cream (half pint w/ vanilla and powdered sugar). Store in fridge until served.

text:
I made it exactly as the recipe described. I measured the sweetened condensed milk, and 3 cups was way too much; you can barely taste the lime. Just two 14-oz. cans would have been plenty. 
I cooked 10 minutes and tiny bubbles never appeared on the surface. I think it  was because of the huge amount of sweetened condensed milk. Remember, the number of ounces on the can is by weight and when you count cups it is fluid ounces.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super easy, super delicious - my fave kind of recipe!
Followed the advice of others and used 2 (300ml) cans of sweetened condensed milk. Didn't have key limes so I used 3 regular limes - which made exactly 3/4-cup of lime juice, and 2 rinds for zest made 1-tbsp. Made my own graham cracker crust (1-1/4 cup graham crumbs & 1/3-cup melted butter, pressed into a 12" pie pan). I baked in convection at 325 and had no idea how to tell if it was done... I left it in for 12-minutes which worked out perfect. Chilled in the fridge for an hour. Delicious!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe with the sour cream.  However there are no eggs in this recipe. Why do you need to bake it? You can just mix the filling, pour it into the crust, top with whipped cream and chill in the fridge overnight. Or you could use a little gelatin to set the filling a little more. Also, try using a dash of ground coriander in the filling. Coriander and lime are a classic flavor combination and you'll be pleasantly surprised how well it works in Key Lime Pie. You could also put some finely minced cilantro in the whipped cream topping instead of coriander in the filling. It's a nice green garnish and tastes awesome with lime!

I made the pie the night before we ate it, following directions, except I used light sour cream and condensed milk.  It. The pie had a slightly gritty texture.  Only one person in a group of 4 finished their piece (my loyal husband).  I'll probably make it again, but use full fat products and let it set even longer than  24  hours.

text:
I made this recipe exactly as suggested, making my own graham cracker crust.  As others pointed out 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk was perfect.  I used bottled Key Lime juice (Nellie & Joe's of Key West) and it was delicious.  My husband said it was better than any we've had in the Keys (we live in Miami).  I think the juice is key to a perfect pie as some others complained of too much tartness, this was not at all a problem and I did use the zest of one lime.  I added home made whipped cream and spread it over all.  I love how easy this pie is and how delicious.

text:
Amazing!! Seriously, best key lime pie ever! I made it and everybody loved it so much I had to make it again a few days later. I've never liked key lime pie and even I couldn't get enough. And I love how easy and foolproof the recipe is. I use the popular graham cracker crust recipe from this site and its delicious. (FYI, if you don't want to measure out the condensed milk...each 14oz can is just a little over a cup. So if you just pour almost all of 3 cans straight into the bowl and don't scrape it down, it should be about 3 cups. There should be just a little left in each can)

text:
Hands down the best key lime pie I've ever had. I followed the recipe except I had regular limes in the fridge I needed to use up before they went bad. 

If using regular limes, if they are on the small side, you will need 6-7 limes. I used twice the lime peel because I like it.  This recipe is a keeper. next time I'm going to double it and make it in a cake pan for bars. 

Also, after it has cooled, I topped with whip cream dollops and more grated lime peel. Yummy and pretty.

While this is a simple recipe to follow, most people do not realise/know that the original Key Limes are from the Florida Keys. text:
So easy and yummy! The only things I changed was making them into mini pies in muffin cups (I used Carol's recipe "Graham Cracker Crust I" which turned out perfectly) and using limes instead of key limes. Neither gave me any problems. It turned out wonderfully and looked fancy without having to put in a huge amount of effort. 
When I was serving these at a party, I decided to make them prettier by I adding two drops green dye to the filling and making a mixture of half zest half sugar to sprinkle on top of homemade whip cream (cream, powdered sugar, and light corn syrup.)

text:
I made this for a potluck and it was a big hit. I followed the recipe exactly except I left out the lime zest. In the interest of time and the nature of the event, I chose to use pre made graham cracker tart shells (I think they were Keebler brand).  I doubled the recipe and this filled 24 shells exactly.  I used the juice of about 45 key limes and 5 cans of condensed milk.  I topped with homemade whipped cream when I served them.  This recipe is good, quick and easy. I think other similar flavors could be substituted for the lime.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually use a recipe that requires eggs so I was very interested to try this egg-free version.
I much rather this recipe's texture; its rich and creamy as opposed to pudding-like, as it is with the egg based recipe. 
The only thing I wasn't a fan of, and I suppose this comes down to personal taste, was using two cans of sweetened condensed milk as it was far too sweet for me. I've since cut this back to 1.5 425g cans.
For those bakers living in Australia, I make my own biscuit base with 18 Arnnots Nice biscuits (crumb in the food processor or whack the living daylights out of them with a rolling pin in a ziplock bag), 100g unsalted melted butter and a good pinch of cinnamon. Mix well then press into a 8-inch pie dish using a dessert spoon. Cook for 15 min at 180c. Cool slightly before dumping in the pie filling (you'll need 4-6 "normal" limes) and cook at the same temperature for 12 min.

text:
This is the easiest dessert I've ever made and it was so good, my family wanted me to make it twice...so I did.  I made the crust from graham crackers, butter and tourbino sugar and it cooked just fine in the 20 minutes it took for the custard to lightly bubble.  I added more lime than the recipe called for in the first batch because my gang likes it tart.  In the second batch I ran out of 'extra' lime, so I add bottled lemon juice and it was even better!  This is a perfect dessert.

Display Name:
mrp0612

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband's mini key lime tree produced about 20 key limes this summer and they all dropped recently around the same time. What to do when life hands you key limes? Make key lime pie! 

I stumbled across this very simple and wonderful recipe. I made a couple of accidental edits, so I'll share them here. I had a small 8 oz container of sour cream - and when I scooped out the required amount, there wasn't much left in the cup, so I just used the whole 8 oz. container. That said, I used 2 whole cans of the sweetened condensed milk - as it came to 28 oz., and I believe this recipe calls for 24 oz. It was the perfect ratio. My husband hand-squeezed the limes (and out of the 20 or so that dropped, he probably used about 12 - some were much bigger than others). We rolled them on the counter first to extract more juice from each one. We strained the juice to get rid of the seeds. I didn't have the ability to get a whole tablespoon of zest, so I probably got more like a teaspoon, but it was perfect as it was. Everything else was done according to the instructions. 

The end results was a perfectly set pie and a wonderful blend of sweet and tart. We didn't garnish with a single thing. If we had, it would have likely taken this recipe over the top. 

Will I make this again? YES! I have never done so before because I thought it would be a hassle. It was certainly not. This particular recipe was really great and I wonder if the person who posted it has another recipe that includes a meri
Review:
Rating:
5

2017-01-17T22:40:33.483

I have just two notes: 1) this pie is way better if you make it the night before you serve it, the flavors just meld together so much better. 2) I never saw the bubbles, and I've made this pie 5-6 times and it never fails that it needs to cook closer to 12-14 minutes vs 8. I have made this as one large pie and also as individual pies.  Both ways it has worked out very well.  Delicious.  I have used bottled key lime juice when I can't get key limes and used the zest of a regular lime and the recipe is still good. None
text:
Easy to make.  I used Nellie & Joe's Famous Key Lime juice because I couldn't find any key limes in my area.  I know die hard key lime pie foodies say you havecto use fresh but don't let that stop you from using Nellie & Joe's if that is all you can get your hands on.  It turned out great.  I would make it again!  You can probably get away with 2 cans of condensed milk since you use a 9 inch graham cracker crust.   If you use 3 cups, you need 3 cans and will end up wasting some.

This pie has gotten rave reviews multiple times from my dinner guests! I made the pie with a homemade graham cracker crust, and also added fresh homemade whipped cream. If you only use one side of your line for the zest, you can cut it into lime wheels after and add on top of whipped topping for a prettier presentation. Don't change anything about the recipe for the pie itself; it's perfect exactly as it is written.

text:
I would never make this recipe again. It makes WAY TOO MUCH filling. I made my normal graham cracker crust in a 9-inch glass pie dish that I always have used for custard pies. I had to run to the store to pick up more graham crackers to make a second pie! Try the Classic Key Lime Pie instead! Essentially the same pie but NORMAL filling.  If you'd use a deep dish pie dish it would MAYBE fit, but even that is pushing it.
