text:
Wow, this was incredible.  Couldn't find key limes, so used regular limes you can always find at the grocery store. It took 6 medium limes to get 3/4 of a cup of lime juice.  Otherwise, I followed the recipe exactly.  

It turned out light and creamy with a lovely, fresh lime flavor.  I don't have much of a sweet tooth, but even I ate two pieces in one sitting!!!

A previous reviewer mentioned using a garlic press to juice the limes and that was a GREAT idea!  had to quarter them, but I got all the juice out of those limes with very little effort.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was incredibly easy and tasty! I agree with others, it took about 20 key limes for 3/4 cup of juice.  I used 2 14oz cans of fat free condensed milk; I discarded 4oz (1/2 cup) then just used the other 24oz (i.e. 3 cups).  This filled out my 9" graham cracker crust perfectly; I made the crust out of reduced fat graham crackers and also added pecans when processing.  I am not a fan of sour cream, so I substituted Greek yogurt; this turned out great.  I'm considering using my favorite Ellenos lemon curd Greek yogurt in the future to see what that's like.  Lastly, I added a little key lime juice and zest to my whipped cream; this made the flavors marry together nicely and made garnish optional.

text:
This was my first attempt at Key Lime Pie - wish I had been making this for years!  I received nothing but rave reviews on this when I served it as Mini Pies using prepared 5" graham cracker crusts.  One recipe serves 12 mini pies.  

The only thing that didn't work out for me was the juicing of the key limes.  I found that I got only HALF the juice expected from everyone else's reviews.  I guess in Wisconsin we don't get the best (biggest & juiciest) key limes.  Argh.  

Other than having to juice my 55 key limes (2#) & still having to supplement the lime juice, these were exceptional.  Just hope I can find some bigger key limes next time!

text:
I used ½ c Nellie & Joe's Key Lime Juice and ¼ c fresh squeezed lemon juice and doubled the amount of lime zest. I whipped it a bit extra with a mixer, and it fills a large pie crust (the rest goes into a few little tart crusts). Baked it 12-14 minutes. After cooling in fridge overnight I drizzled fresh lime juice over the top, and then decoratively covered with lime slices. This is the perfect key lime pie from a simple, egg-free recipe.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was an easy and fantastic recipe  - turned out super creamy and delicious!  I have a bunch of limes in my backyard, so I used about 6 large limes to get 3/4 cup of juice.  I usually make my own graham crackers crust, but had six store bought mini graham cracker crusts, so I used those thinking the filling would fit..... When the mini shells were completely full, I still had half the filling left! So I filled a few ramekins with the remaining filling, topped with a few crushed graham crackers mixed with a little sugar and butter, and baked them for about 10 to 12 minutes until the graham crackers topping was crisp.  Topped with fresh whipped cream, the mini pies and my improvised key lime pie "crisp" were both delicious!  Thanks for a great and versatile recipe!

text:
This was my first attempt at key lime pie and it was perfect and tasted very authentic.  A few things...I used full fat Fage Greek yogurt instead of sour cream.  I actually think this improved the recipe (in my opinion).  Also, I forgot the lime zest, but it still tasted awesome.  A note about the cooking time, and this may apply to others using old (or maybe just mine?) ovens.  After 5 minutes, I checked for bubbles on top and there was nothing.  I checked every 2-3 minutes from then on and still no bubbles.  I kept going but worried I did something wrong.  At just under the 25 minute mark, I finally started seeing bubbles.  I'm guessing my apartment oven must be working at a much lower temperature than it's supposed to.  Anyway, this tasted perfect and my family loved it.  I actually think it tastes much better the next day once fully chilled and all the flavors set in.

country:
None
text:
Hands down the easiest, quickest, and most delicious recipe I have ever found for cream pie. I have used this recipe, and several variations of it, many times now without ever having one issue. I always use 2 cans (14oz) sweetened condensed milk per pie, and instead of sour cream I use plain Greek yogurt or plain whole milk yogurt. I have substituted the key lime juice with lemon juice, grapefruit juice, pink grapefruit juice, and several other citrus juices (and substituted their perspective zest as well)  with the exact same results; perfect! For a twist, I also have used shortbread cookie crumb crust as well as gingersnap cookie crumb crust with equal success as a substitute for the graham cracker crust.  Thanks for a showstopper of a dish!

Excellent. Followed the recipe exactly (minus the lime zest as I'm not fond of it) every single time. I've made this 4 times and every time it was gone in 5 minutes at every party because after the first person tried it, the news quickly spread to grab some before it was gone! city:

country:

text:
I made this for a Fourth of July party yesterday. It was a HUGE hit! I heard people talking about how good it was, and they didn't even know I made it. It made me super star! And it is so easy.  I will give 2 tips. One, Walmart sold a bag of 20 key limes and that was exactly right. Be sure to strain your juice before adding it to other ingredients, You might have seeds in there. Also, I did the full 3 cups of sweetened condensed milk, which is 2 cans PLUS about 2/3 cups from a third can. The only reason I didn't just use the 2 cans was because I was also working on another recipe that didn't call for a the whole can of sweetened condensed milk and had some left over, which turned out perfectly. I guess if I had just used the 2 cans it wouldn't have been as sweet and maybe not as good? I'm not sure I'm willing to try it that way now that everyone thought this one was so good.

text:
Absolutely the best Key Lime Pie I've ever eaten!   The only changes I made were (1)  I added 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk, which measured approximately 2 1/2 cups.   Another half-cup would have made the pie too sweet; and (2) I added only about 2 teaspoons of grated lime zest, and that was plenty.   I'm not usually keen on using zest, but it really did enhance the flavor of this pie.   I baked my pie for a full 8 minutes.    I used 8 fresh limes (3/4 c. juice)  vs. bottled juice.  Everyone I shared the pie with loved it!  This recipe is definitely a keeper!

text:
Absolutely delicious!  I love key lime pie, especially in the summer time because it is such a refreshing and light dessert.  I normally make another recipe that has cream cheese as the base ingredient and wanted to try a different version.  So I picked this one and I'm so glad that I did!  This one is a bit more sweet and richer than the other recipe that I make and has a little more of a creamier texture.  But it is soo good that I will have to add this version to make along with our other favorite.  I did cook it 10 min. total and only saw maybe 3 little tiny bubbles on the top.  It sat up in the fridge perfectly.  2 cans of condensed milk almost equals the 3 cups.  And since I didn't have key limes, I used regular limes and it took 3 large limes to make the full 3/4 cup of juice for the recipe.  Thank you for the delicious recipe!!  It is so good!

text:
I used 8 mexican limes to get 3/4 cup of juice, 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk, as recommended by reviewers, light sour cream and the zest.  I made a home made crust with the crumbs from 8 full graham crackers, 6 T of melted butter and 1/3 cup of sugar, packed firmly into a 9 inch pie pan and pre baked for 6 minutes at 350. The filling was the perfect amount for the 9 inch pie pan, and it was FABULOUS! Even my husband, who doesn't crave key lime pie, as I do, said it was the best he ever had.

text:
Excellent recipe, but I need to comment on the graham cracker crust.  Living in Florida, I read a research article on Key Lime Pie in a 1987 Ft. Lauderdale paper.   It stated the crust of the Key West original pie was a pastry crust as graham crackers were not in existence.  I follow the Key West original crust and it does justice to the very sweet filing.  Too sweet for the rich graham cracker  crust.  Mother Butler's pie store never made it with anything but pastry crust.  It was superb

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2720436.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very easy. I made my own graham cracker crust which was two packs of Honey Maid Graham Crackers, crushed and 1 1/2 sticks of salted butter, softened. I loved it and the two comments I got from two different people were, "This is something that you'd find at a nice restaurant." and, "I tried not to eat that so fast, but I couldn't help it." If you make this and refrigerate it over night, it is even better. I also made my own strawberry topping, which was 12-16 oz strawberries and 1 cup sugar, cooked on med-high in a sauce pan for 20 minutes, then cooled overnight. Home made whip cream was also a great topping and doesn't steal any of the glory from the key lime like the strawberries do. Use a spring-form pan for easy slicing and serving.

text:
This is my go to key lime pie recipe. I up the amounts to accommodate the amount I need, and I skip the baking all together. It doesn't affect the finished product. 3 cans condensed milk, 1 cup sour cream and 1 cup lime juice. Just mix, pour and chill. Perfection every time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm sure that this recipe does not need one more review, but maybe my experience will help someone else - I live in Mexico, where there are NO graham crackers, but I can occasionally find a premade graham cracker crust at our local Walmart or Costco. (Go figure.)  So I take two of them, dump them into a food processor and add a bit (1/4 cup) of melted butter and the same amount of sugar. Whip it up and then I use an 11-inch tart pan for the pie. I also top it with whipped cream and some grated lime zest. It is beautiful and it is delicious. Thanks for the fine recipe.

text:
I live in the Keys 7 months out of the year and travel to Ohio for the other 5... left my Key Lime Pie recipe at the other house :-( I found this one; an exact match to the one I use. I DO make my own graham cracker crust :-) My many many friends have stated that this is the BEST Key Lime Pie they have ever had; ONE TIP: Serve the slices with whipped cream and a small wedge of Key Lime on each slice. I have also put them into mini paper-lined foil cupcake papers and brought them to BBQs etc with whipped cream and limes on the side... always a BIG bite-sized hit!! ENJOY this "taste of the islands"!!

This was a great pie.  I made it for a get together and everyone loved it.  I was a little short on key limes so I used just under 3/4 cup and I was short on the condensed milk.  I used 2 cans which didn't come out to 3 cups.  Nonetheless, it was very tasty and I'll make it again.  I made my own graham crust using  Graham Cracker Crust I.  There wasn't quite enough filling but it could be because I was a little short on ingredients.  Next time I'm going to try freezing it and covering a slice in chocolate like they do in Key West.

text:
This was so easy to make as one of my Christmas desserts.  I let the butter and cream cheese sit out about 5 hours so they were super soft. I used about 8-10 fresh limes, instead of store bought lime juice.  After baking the pie for about 8-10 minutes.  I let cool, and I refrigerated over night. The pie was perfect.  It had a light and fluffy tastes. It gelled together perfectly. The next time I make it , I will actually make the crust instead of using the store bought, I found the store bought crust to be a tad bit dry.  Overall the pie was excellent.  I would definitely recommend.

This is my first time rating a recipe on any website.  This was also my first time at making a key lime pie.  My husband has particular tastes and likes extremely tart key lime pies.  I made this recipe exactly as written.  My only neutral comment was that I had way too much filling for my graham cracker crust.  I believe I over filled the crust.  I probably could have made 2 key lime pies with this recipe.  Therefore, I had to cook it much longer than the recipe called for.  However, when it was done and we savored it on Thanksgiving Day, it was perfection!  It was the biggest hit of all the pies I made (I made 9 total!) and my husband was in love.  He told me to use more lime juice and zest next time to make it more tart ... however, everyone else said it had the perfect blend of sweetness to tartness.  Even my father-in-law who is the pickiest eater I know LOVED it.  I have a gluten intolerance so I made my own gluten-free graham cracker crust and no one was the wiser.  Absolutely delicious!!!  It was also incredibly easy to put together.  It took no time at all and even with cooking it longer, it wasn't in the oven for more than 20 minutes.  Will DEFINITELY make again!  Probably for Christmas LOL.  Next time, I will make 2 pies with this recipe :)

text:
My husband is a Florida native and grew up on traditional Key Lime pie.  Short on time as usual, I used a prepared graham cracker crust, bottled key lime juice from the Florida Keys, and 2 cans of fat-free condensed milk. The only thing I did differently was to add 2 Tbsp of fresh lemon juice to the filling mixture. Fabulous, easy and oh-so-good. You have to try this!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2862797.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great pie. Just a note that if you live in Florida and get your key limes ripe falling right off the tree, they are so juicy that you will have your 3/4 cup of key lime juice with just about a 1/2 dozen key limes so be sure to measure. The garlic press for squeezing is a GENIUS tip. Thank you ljm4mr for that! My first pie came out a little tart, according to my father, who is the family's biggest celebrated host, foodie, and recipe critic. The antidote to tartness--or for those who just like things sweeter--is to add a little (or a lot of) sugar depending on the sweet tooth of your audience. On the one hand the sweetened condensed milk should be sweet enough, but for those who believe dessert can never be too sweet, or that you should always add more sugar than the recipe calls for, go ahead and add some regular white sugar, according to taste.

text:
This was the first time I ever made key lime pie. The recipe is so easy and turns out great! I made it for my friend's birthday and everyone loved it! 20 key limes really does turn out to be 3/4 of a cup on the dot, but I had the birthday girl taste it to see if it was tart enough. We like our lime pie really tart so I added more juice. For those that don't like tartness I would recommend only adding a 1/2 cup of lime juice to start and then tasting it as more is added. This recipe was a huge hit!

As another reviewer mentioned, 2 cans of sweetened condensed milk is enough. I add 3 eggs yolks to make it more creamy. One bag of key limes is enough to make the 3/4 cup required. Used a crust recipe from Sally's Baking Addiction. Bake for 15 minutes, which is what other recipes with the added egg recommend.

text:
Here's the scoop: this recipe is pretty decent. However: it's too rich - I'd change the ratio of the milk and cream to be a bit heavier on the sour cream side (it was almost sickeningly sweet); the filling was too much for the crust, so I would recommend just filling the crust to level with the edge or maybe a bit more, but don't overdo it, as I did; using  the key limes from my neighbor's tree only required 11. But whatever it takes to get to 3/4 c. is cool. They were about 1/2 in to 1 inch in diameter.

Display Name:
ABoston

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/36361.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent pie!    I make two changes.  First, I make my own crust.    Graham cracker crusts are easy and foolproof, and I think they are a lot tastier than pre-made.  It's also a fun way for kids to help:  Combine 1 1/2 c cracker crumbs (a little more than one packet),  1/8 c sugar, and 1/4 c melted butter.   Press into a pie tin and let cool before adding pie filling.        My second change is to add meringue.    In a *completely dry* mixing bowl, beat 4 egg whites until foamy.  Gradually add 6T sugar until the whites form stiff peaks.  Spread meringue over the pie, completely covering and SEALING EDGES.     Bake at 350 for 10- 15 min on a medium rack, until edges and tips of peaks are brown.   Chill before serving.

text:
This is the only KLP recipe we use. I've been to Key West many times and this rivals even the best @ the various restaurants there.
Don't fool with juicing key limes. Buy Nellis & Joe's Key West Lime Juice. Comes in 16 oz. bottle-found in bottled juices aisle in stores like Publix & Kroger. Make yr own crust if you have the time. Divine.

text:
I love key lime pie and this recipe taste great and is easy to make.  I've made this recipe a few times and each time I get loads of compliments on how good it taste.  Not only that it is so easy to make.  The hardest part about this is squeezing the key limes.  Wal-ly world sales bags of key limes periodically.  I've used store bought graham cracker crust and have made my own.  Either way, its very good.  Key lime pie is typically extremely rich and sweet, so I only eat a little at a time.

My first key lime pie, and at the recommended temperature after 8 minutes it did not set. After 15 minutes, did not set. At 20 minutes I took it out and thought maybe it just needed to chill. After 5 hours it was not set, just a gloppy mess. Are we sure there isn't an egg missing somewhere? The taste was fine, but it did not turn into anything that could be cut into a pie slice without melting all over the plate. Probably user error, but...I really did everything the recipe said.

text:
MAKE THIS PIE! I've  made this SUPER EASY pie three times, without the zest because I didn't have any, and I used bottled key lime juice. I use a shortbread crust instead of graham cracker. Let it sit over night to let the flavors mellow. Turns out fabulous! Gushing reviews from my family, including my own mom! 

This recipe opens itself up to all kinds of new pie flavors by using different juices and purees. I'm looking forward to caramelizing the sweetened condensed milk and making a salted caramel cream pie!!!!

userID:
13439658
Display Name:
Erin
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5811153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time trying my hand at Key Lime pie. I love key lime, and was thrilled when my boyfriend asked for this as his birthday treat. I have a mini cupcake pan, and he asked that I make them in this.. so they are bite sized. I did, and they turned out great! The hardest part was the crust. I use the Graham Cracker Crust I recipe from this site for all of my graham cracker crust needs. I scooped 1 rounded Tbsp of crust into each cup in the pan and pressed against the edges with a spoon. For the filling, I used 25 walnut sized key limes, halved them, and juiced them with a garlic press,  as recommended by one of the other reviewers. I did find that a cheese cloth would have been useful, as there were bits of seeds I needed to strain out. I used a thick paper towel and it took forever. I used the recommended 2 cans sweetened condensed milk, and light sour cream. Filled them to the brim and baked for 9 min. They are delicious... and so cute!

text:
I could not find 8 ounce cans of sweetened condensed milk so I used 3 cans, this way none would go to waste.  And in doing so,  I added a little more sour cream and lime juice.  Add the lime juice as you go or to taste.  
I also used a ready made pie crust and cooked the pie crust according to the directions on package before adding the filling.  This cut down on the "sweetness" factor.  
This is by far the BEST key lime pie, ever!!!

This recipe is awesome! I even decided to make it for my friend's wedding after trying it out earlier in the week with great success. My boyfriend says, "This tastes like you bought it at a restaurant!" Used 2 cans of sweetened-condensed milk and Nellie & Joe's Key Lime Juice (found at SafeWay). "Iced" the whole thing with Extra Creamy Cool Whip - perfection! I thought it tasted even better the next day. Will definitely be going back to this recipe again and again!

This pie is an easy five stars. It turned out beautiful and creative with the perfect amount of lime taste. I used Mexican limes instead of Keylime's so that I only had to squeeze six or so to get 3/4 cup fresh lime juice. (Hint: if you don't have a juicer, cut the limes in half, stick a fork in the pulp and twist over a bowl or measuring cup)  I topped with homemade whipped cream. What a great way to taste summer!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the only key lime pie recipe I'll ever use. I made it exactly as the recipe was written. The reviewer that said the pie was bitter may have over-zested the lime, unknowingly adding the bitter tasting layer of the flesh to the pie. Be careful not to go to far into the lime! I always make this in the morning and serve it at least 7-8 hours later. I pipe the edges of the pie with a simple homemade whipped cream at the halfway point of chilling (3-4 hours) so that it sets up nicely. A tiny sprinkle of lime zest (remember to be careful) adds a nice touch. Thank You, Thank You, Thank You for this easy recipe.

text:
I made this as my first try at Key Lime Pie and it was great!  I definitely recommend it.  Just a quick side note, I like measuring our my ingredients (especially when I try a recipe for the first time) and I'm glad I did.  The standard "14 oz" can of condensed milk was actually barely 12 oz when I measured it so I would recommend measuring the condensed milk instead of just using 2 cans.  I'm sure it's not a big deal if you use a little less condensed milk but I think you'll get the consistent flavor every time by having the right ratios of all the ingredients.  Happy tastings!

text:
The filling mixture didn't really want to firm up the first time I made this, and took a long time to chill. I added a brick of cream cheese the second time around and it was better. If you decide to add cream cheese, make sure you let it soften first. Straight from the fridge it will not mix well enough and you will have lumps. 3 stars since I had to alter the recipe. Very tasty to begin with, though.

None
text:
The recipe for me was good, but a little too rich. I adjusted the recipe a bit and now it's perfect for my taste! Everyone loves it and you still get a nice firm set. 

2 C sweetened condensed milk 
1 C sour cream
3/4 C Key lime juice
4 drops green food coloring

Doubling it makes for easy measuring...
For 2 pies I use 3 cans condensed milk and 1 tub of sour cream (16 oz).  

If you're buying a crust look for the larger 9" ones. The regular 8" size is a bit too small for this much filling.

I love key lime pie, but mine turned out bitter both times I made it. I think it must be the zest. I used fresh pressed key lime juice, which wasn't very sour itself. text:
Sickly sweet.  Since I used regular limes (that are common in Toronto, Canada) as an alternative, I rated this recipe a 3.  I rate my "perisan lime" pie a 1. I even used 1 extra lime for juice and extra zest.  The end result was still more sweet than tart.  The lime taste did not come through as much as I would of liked.  Even with the extra juice the pie still came out firm.  I would recommend that you taste the pie filling before you put it in the oven and alter to your taste buds.

None
text:
I used all of the sweetened condensed milk in two cans (28 oz) so I increased the size of the pie by adding 1/4 C more lime juice and a little more sour cream.  I used regular fresh lime juice and zest.

I have made many key lime pies in my life, but this beats them all.  I have NO IDEA if this is authentic key lime pie, but I simply don't care!  It is creamy, tart, sweet and a simple, perfect dessert.  It will be my "go to" recipe from now on.

text:
I didn't change a thing.  I made this for a church gathering, and an old man said Key Lime pie hu?  He got a large piece, found a seat, and set about the task before him.  Some time later he came up to me and told me that he is always skeptical when someone says they brought a Key Lime pie.  He proceeded to tell me he was indeed an expert at Key Lime as it was his very favorite.  He said well.... you indeed brought a Key Lime pie with you, and it is one of the very best I have eaten.  I hope you bring that again some time.  So, take it for what it's worth.  He was no spring chicken, and claims he has spent years eatin pies which folks were claiming to be Key Lime.   Some are, and some ain't, but this one past his test! Enjoy! He did:)

Display Name:
Denise Rolwes Krekeler

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1821426.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie is delicious!  I used about 20 key limes and almost 1 regular lime. To juice the key limes, I sliced off the top and bottoms of each lime, then used a small fork to get all the juice out.  This seemed to be the easiest way, since I was able to rub the inside of the lime against the fork. Don't forget to squeeze the little end peices for an extra few drops of that lime gold. I didn't see any mention if straining the juice, but it was an easy step to a creamy pie. I did grate about 4 key limes to get the zest. I don't know if it adds that much flavor, but it definitely makes for a pretty pie. Easy, not to sweet, not to tart.  It's definitely a keeper!

5

userID:
2286378
Display Name:
waxing witch
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/451789.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i wanted something easy and summery to bring to a labor day cookout yesterday.  i thought about key lime something because i had a bottle of nellie and joe's key lime juice from a failed key lime bar attempt.  when i saw this recipe's rating and how easy it was, i figured i'd give it a try.  the ingredients seemed too easy to be good, but my family is very forgiving of my baking fails - plus i had enough time to whip up something else if needed.  after reading reviews, i decided to go with low fat condensed milk and sour cream (used two 14oz cans of eagle brand low fat condensed milk and daisy low fat sour cream) and bought a premade graham cracker crust because i didn't want to waste time making a crust if it wasn't going to be a keeper recipe.

it's a keeper recipe.  i cooked it for about 14 minutes before i saw a few pinhole bubbles and, after giving it a little shake, it seemed to have set well.  i did not use any lime zest because i didn't want anything to disturb the smooth consistency of the pie.  i cooled it for about 40 minutes on top of the stove, then popped it in the fridge for about 5 hours.  i think it was set properly - we were able to cut it and serve it without too much oozing; i've never made a pie like this so i'm not exactly sure what i was looking for/expecting.  i served it with redi whip and it was a hit.  my brother who has never had key lime pie ate almost an entire piece and said it was good but a little tart for him lol.  definitely a keeper!

userID:
13799446
Display Name:
Karen Jacobs
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1180337.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So many compliments when I make this pie! For the crust, I use the recipe on the Honey Maid graham cracker crumb box. Add in about 1/3 cup of sweetened shredded coconut to the crumbs for a more interesting version. You may have to add in a bit more melted butter depending on the moisture in the coconut. I used 2 cans of condensed milk and increased the lime juice from 3/4c to 1c. Just used good ol' SoCal limes from the neighbor's tree for the juice. I found it helpful to add the grated lime zest by hand, just before you pour the filling into the shell; then the zest won't hang up on your beaters. When serving, add some fresh raspberries and a bit of raspberry coulis to jazz it up!

text:
Image made this pie 4 times now and the recipe is great. However, the lime juice does make a significant difference. I couldn't find key limes the first time I made it and even the regular limes were too expensive to justify it, so I just used regular lime juice (the Real Lemon brand) and it was perfect, not too tart, just the perfect amount of tartness. This last time I found actual Key West key lime juice at Publix and it was just too tart. I am sure if I only use 1/2 cup of the juice amount it would have been perfect. Just keep that in mind if you do not want it too tart.

text:
I made this pie for a pie baking contest at my church this weekend. I had to make a homemade crust per the rules of the contest. I used premade graham cracker crumbs and just followed the recipe on the container. I also used about 24 key limes which measured exactly 3/4 of a cup. It was very easy to make, and I ended up winning the contest!  I was pretty excited because this is the first pie I've ever made!! I highly recommend this recipe!

This was a simple key lime pie and was the right texture but mine was barely not tart enough.  It is hard to count points off for that since the key limes are a produce item and vary so much in acidity and tartness.  That said, next time I will try it with all the same measurements except I will just use two cans of milk instead of three cups.  Thank you for the recipe.  We enjoyed it very much.

Key Lime pie is my favorite! This recipe tops any that I have had and is by far soo.. simple.  I baked it for work for someones birthday and it was a huge hit. text:
This recipe is so wonderful, my husband and I can polish off a whole pie in a day and a half!  I follow the recipe almost exactly, the exception being I only use 2 cans (about 2 cups) of sweetened condensed milk.  I don't think I would like it with all three cups, it would be way to sweet I think. With two cups it is the PERFECT balance of sweet and tart for us, and fills the pie crust perfectly.  I top it with whipped cream I make with 3 TBS of powdered sugar and grate lime zest over it to make it pretty. So happy I found this recipe!  One last little hint- you can make it with any type of lime and I find it's delicious either way ;) I may try it with lemon juice just to experiment next time.

country:
None
text:
Absolutely the best Key Lime Pie... hands down!  My daughter & I made this along with Allrecipes.com Graham Cracker Crust I, by Carol, and Easy Whipped  Cream, by Thymekeeper.
We used approx. 30 Key Limes to get 3/4 C. juice.   The best way to juice the Key Limes is to cut them in half then press the juice out using a garlic press... I learned this tip from reviewer, ljm4mr.  It took 2 1/2 (14oz.) cans of condensed milk = 3 C.  We garnished the pie with left over graham cracker crumbs and lime slices, and served it with a few fresh raspberries on the side which were a very nice compliment to the pie.
This recipe is so easy and it is so delicious that I am thinking about asking my girlfriend if I can sell it in her restaurant. :-)  ...And this is coming from a girl who hates to cook!

Tried this easy recipe for my very fussy daughter in law and it was a resounding smash.. No Key Limes, but regular limes which I froze to be able to grate the zest. Then zapped the frozen limes in micro to juice…added the pulp to the mixture, but one secret I think was to let the grated rind mix in with the lime juice. Can hardly wait to use real Key Limes.  Highly, highly recommend this dessert..so easy  Oh…yes, two cans of sweetened condensed milk add up to three cups. Topped it with whipped cream and strawberries.

text:
I made this yesterday from a Recipe card that came in a pot holder gift set. Anyways I was looking on allrecipes to see how it compared and the same recipe is there verbatim . It's so good and easy you have to try it!!!  
like some of the reviewers said I used 2 14 oz cans of sweetened condensed milk-which is about 2 1/2 cups measured out (not over 3 cups like it should be) but my pie turned out perfect. I also used 3/4 cup key-west lime juice instead of key limes. it was great!!! I baked mine for about 10-11 min and never saw the bubbles it was talking about but took it out and it set up really nicely we were able to dig into it after dinner even though I made it just before!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie was a real hit with my friends and family!! My son wanted me to make this for his 21st birthday. Being Australian I had never tried one before much less made one so I went to this site in search of the best recipe I could find and this one seemed a good bet! I had to change the crust as I am a coeliac. I made up the crust with 1 x175g packet of gluten free shortbread biscuits - processed to crumbs, 1 x 250g almond meal and 1 egg to bind. I pricked it with a fork and blind baked it for 8 mins. Then just made the filling and baked it as per the recipe with one small edition of a shot of good white rum because that's what my son wanted and a little extra juice and zest as we don't get Key Limes here. No one at the party had tried it before but everyone loved it and asked for a copy of the recipe. Thanks Ann - It's a WINNER!!!!

text:
My youngest son has been requesting a key lime pie, so I came here to look for one. I made this for New Year's Eve and it was fabulous. I thawed a small tub of cool whip and spread a layer on top of the cooled pie before serving. I also have a confession...I did not have any key limes or key lime juice, so I just used the bottled lime juice (ReaLime) that I had on hand and it worked just as well. And actually, if anything, the pie was a little less bitter than with the key lime juice, which I prefer but my son wants me make it with actual key limes to compare. Great recipe!

country:
None
text:
Great recipe and I don't like Key Lime Pie! 
To my nature I added the following to the recipe & had no complaints.....only repeat co-workers asking for another slice:
Lime flavored Rum...2-3oz
Whipped Cream Vodka...just shy of 1oz
3 cans of sweetened condensed milk and Sour cream about 3/4 cup (to make up for the added liquid)! 
I also added about 3oz of the Whipped Cream Vodka and some grated lime zest (about 2 limes worth)  to some Cool Whip for a very decidant whipped cream topping but only in the center of the pie not over the whole thing. 
Super easy, super delicious thanks for such a great recipe!!!!

Amazing!! Made it for Xmas 2013 and it was a hit! I used 2 cans of condensed milk like others suggested and all the listed ingredients. I defrosted a container of cool whip and used about 1/4 of it just enough to cover the pie. Hardest part was squeezing the limes on my garlic press but it was soo worth it when I tasted it! The fresh lime flavor really comes through. This is our new favorite pie, pumpkin cheesecake move over! I plan to use this recipe again but maybe with a version of condensed milk made of coconut milk to make it somewhat healthier. Love it!

text:
Initial reaction:  This is a little bitter.  I don't know if it was the limes or what.  From 28 key limes (one bag) I got just shy of 3/4 cup of juice.  I decided not to supplement with bottled, as I did not want to sully the flavor.  I zested perhaps 8 limes before cutting and squeezing to get a little over a tablespoon of zest.

I will update when we have more tomorrow and it is fully chilled, not just slightly cool.  We may add ice cream as well.

Update:  Definitely let this sit overnight!  The lime is stronger, there isn't that weird bitter taste, and being fully chilled really helps.  Also, I think I will pick up an actual citrus zester, instead of using my box grater, to avoid getting pith with my zest.

userID:
5027478
Display Name:
Kyi
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:

5

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1345217.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's easy to make, requires only a few ingredients, and tastes great! All around good recipe. I used a Keebler pre-made graham crust and Nellie and Joe's bottled key lime juice to save time. I also don't like overly sweet desserts and tasted the mixture before pouring it into my crust, and here's what I changed to make it more palatable for me. I only used 1 and a half can of the sweetened condensed milk and substituted the rest with coconut milk (you can use coconut cream as well) and used a little extra sour cream. I also added the zest of one regular lime and in a small ramekin, I made a similar mixture with a few drops of peppermint extract, as I thought a creamy, coconutty, tart, and a zing of refreshing mint would make it more interesting. I baked the pie for approximately 15 minutes, as the pinhole bubbles are kinda hard to see, but it was fine. I let it rest in the oven for a bit, then let it cool off on the counter before storing it in the fridge to chill. My boyfriend said the smaller "sample/experiment" key lime pie tasted kinda like a peppermint patty. I thought it was good but if you try this, be careful to not add too much mint as it will take away from the creamy/tartness of the actual pie. The coconut milk was a nice variation if you're looking to try something slightly different.
Review:

5

text:
All I can say is, "WOW!"  I live in Florida, have been making Key Lime Pie all my life using the "traditional" recipe: key lime juice, 1 can of condensed milk, and 3 egg yolks.  It is a good, simple recipe, but the pie crust is only 2/3 filled, and I'm left with 3 egg whites that I am usually guilted into turning into a meringue topping. This recipe is, well, SUPERIOR! The flavor is delightful, it sets up quickly, and the pie shell is filled almost to overflowing! I used 2 cans of condensed milk and cooked for about 10 minutes.  This will be the recipe I use from now on.  THANK YOU!

Display Name:
KrystalH

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this with Graham Cracker Crust I (cinnamon omitted) from this site, and it turned out great. I haven't had Key Lime Pie in years, but this is exactly what I remember it tasting like. I used a pre-packed bag of key limes, so I didn't count them. I did use the garlic press trick - works great. I had let the limes sit in my fridge longer than I should have, and they were turning brown, so I only got about 1/2 tbsp of zest off them. I don't think I would use the full tbsp next time, though, anyways - I find the flavor to be exactly strong enough as it is. I also used two cans of sweetened condensed milk. Baked it for about 9 minutes. It set up very nicely, and hasn't deteriorated at all after sitting in the fridge uncovered overnight. I think for a crowd I would try making it in bars - it seems quite firm enough for that. All in all, great recipe.

text:
I've made this pie time and again for my husband.  It is definitely his favorite.  It turns out well every time.  We've also tried the Emeril's key lime, which is good and a little less sweet, but tricky to make and can sometimes fail for unexplained reasons.  I also suggest a spoonful of bourbon whip cream to top it off.  It makes the perfect compliment to cut the sweetness.  Thank you for a great recipe!  Easy to make and turns out perfect every time.  I will say, I ususally have to bake mine for closer to 14 minutes to get the bubbles, but it has never burned or ruined the flavor.

I was hesitant to make this because I wanted to use fresh key limes, but didn't want the work entailed with trying to squeeze the juice from the oh so small key limes, until my husband suggested I use a garlic press. text:
I made this yesterday. Limes are small here so it really needed about 40 limes since I doubled the recipe. Also, I only used 2.5 cups of condensed milk and I thought it was plenty sweet and it firmed up in oven and the refrigerator just fine.

If I were to make it next time, I would go even lower on the sweetened condensed milk to 2 cups and I bet it will be plenty sweet and still hold together.

Finally, I used the gluten free graham crackers for a crust and it was fabulous.

text:
Wow! This was absolutely fabulous!  Just the right combination of sweet, tart, and creamy.  Super easy to make, too.  I'd give this 10 stars, if I could,, and am tossing all other key lime pie recipes, as there is absolutely no way to beat this.  It was quick and easy to make because I used bottled Key Lime juice and two cans of store-brand sweetened condensed milk.  (Here in the Pacific NW, I found the key lime juice at New Seasons Market).  The only thing I did differently, was to make my own "graham cracker crust", using the recipe submitted to this site by Carole.

country:

text:
This is the best Key Lime Pie I have ever made and one of the easiest.  I followed the recipe with the exception of squeezing the limes.  Instead I used Mott's "RealLime" juice.  I did buy one lime so I could get the zest and used a couple of slices for decoration with real whipping cream.  Another use for this recipe is for parfaits.  Just make the filling in a pie pan without the crust and bake as normal.  When the filling is cooled, layer in glasses with graham cracker crumbs, whipping cream and filling.  I took them to a potluck in clear plastic cups and they were the hit of the party!

text:
Does this pie really need another review?!! I was so easy, so fast to whip together with ingredients that I almost always have on hand...and absolutely delicious! I used persian limes because I had a whole bag but next time (which will be soon! I might even have a spring dinner party just so I have an excuse to make this pie) I'll use key limes. Even making my own graham crust, I think this only took about 1/2 hour to throw together on Easter Sunday morning; chilled all day in the fridge and it was the perfect light and fresh dessert for a ham dinner. Everyone loved it. Thanks!

Display Name:
Candice Kalinski

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5918300.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I believe this is one of the best key lime pie recipes I've found!  I didn't realize how good this pie could turn out with the absence of eggs, but it did.  I made my own graham cracker crust, used two cans of sweetened condensed milk as others have posted, and substituted greek yogurt for the sour cream.  Since I do not own a citrus juicer, I just bought organic lime juice in the bottle.  I also added four True Lime packets as I like a very tart pie (personal preference).  I would say the most time consuming part in my opinion is making the graham cracker crust.  But after preparing the crust (I let it sit in the refrigerator an hour before filling), the rest of the ingredients come together in no time at all.  The cook time of 8 minutes is probably about right even though I let it sit in the oven for 10 minutes.  After chilling, I decorate it with a homemade whipped cream border and enjoy.  Thank you for sharing!

text:
I followed the filling recipe (using Joe & Nellie's bottled KL juice) but for adding 1 T regular lime juice from the lime I used for the zest, & low fat sour cream. For the crust I chose to use 'Nabisco Famous Chocolate Wafers' (available too expensively from Amazon...in many large supermarkets)--crushed in food processor w/, 1/2 t. cinnamon, 3 T. sugar & 6 T. melted butter pressed into 8" springform pan, partly up the side. Save some crumbs to sprinkle on top of the whipped cream (I used real) used to 'frost' the pie. I see that Oreo crusts are available in the store, but I prefer homemade. Excellent recipe. I don't know if it would work, but I'm thinking about folding egg whites into the filling to make it lighter and fluffier next time. Not sure how to adjust baking time with that change, though.

This was SOOO easy!  The only change I made was instead of 3 cups of sweetened condensed milk, I used 2 - 300 ml cans and it was perfect.  I actually had a little too much filling for the crust. I'm not an experienced pie maker by any stretch, but you'd never know it by the way this turned out!  Highly, highly recommended recipe!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5997417.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe has all the taste but it's not quite right yet. I like the idea of using sour cream and ommitting the egg yolks because you don't get that eggy residue taste in your mouth.  The lime becomes the real star where flavor is concerned.

Though I tried to follow the directions exactly as written, the end result is that the filling didn't set up right.  I ended up making an executive decision to continue baking it in the oven more than twice as long than the recipe suggested because 5-8 minutes was just a joke.  I now wish I would have baked it for another 10 minutes as I wonder if that would have resulted in a firmer consistency.  I will probably try that in the next go.

Does anyone have a suggestion for how this recipe - using just fresh lime juice, condensed milk and sour cream can result in a pie fillign that is not goey or runny?  

PS - I got 3/4 cup of lime juice from exactly 6 limes.  That was a nice surprise!

country:
None
text:
This pie is wonderful! My family and coworkers have all told me it's the best key lime pie they have had.

Condensed milk comes in 14 oz cans. 2 cans = 28 oz. Recipe calls for 3 cups. 1 cup = 8 oz; 3 cups = 24 oz. The four extra ounces are fine in this recipe. Just pour in the two cans and it will turn out great. Don't worry if you have key limes or not. The biggest difference between them and just a regular lime is size. Normal limes are much easier to juice and zest. The flavor difference between the two types of limes is not much. They are limes, they will all be very acidic and limey! You will, however, notice a difference if you decide to use pre-bottled lime juice over freshly squeezed lime juice!

text:
This is a really good pie!  I've had many key lime pies that were just so-so.  I was able to find the little key limes in my regular grocery store but wasn't looking forward to squeezing them.  Luckily, my husband found the key lime juice at Smart and Final (of all places!). I didn't have quite enough and still had to juice about 8 little limes.  Otherwise I stuck to the recipe exactly.  So incredibly easily!  I wasn't sure whether to add the zest, but I did.  Added a nice subtle zing and homemade feeling.  Made it for Thanksgiving and people who don't normally like pies or anything sweet, loved this pie!  I plan on making it again and again.  Will be my go to pie.  Next time I might try making my own graham cracker crust, but the store bought was a big hit too.  I used 2 cans condensed milk like the other reviewers said and it was perfect.  Had exactly enough for a nicely filled, full 9 in regular pie.  Added whipped cream and the lime decorations before serving, and it looked so pretty and professional.  It was almost impossible to see the pinholes at 6-8 min, so cooked for 10 and it was perfect.  I could see the pinholes when I took it out (incredibly hard to see and so small, that I say just cook 10 min and be done).  Set perfectly, no problems.  Giving it 5 stars for being so tasty and so EASY.

text:
Very thick, rich texture. Whatever you do (I still cannot believe I did this), MAKE CERTAIN YOUR BOTTLED KEY LIME JUICE IS NOT SWEETENED. And make sure it's key lime juice AT ALL! Apparently companies can market sweetened, regular lime juice from concentrate as "key lime juice". SHAME! Be "stingy" with those servings to guests--they come back if they want some more. Serve a sliver with a generous dollop of a chic yellow-green hued whipped cream and some zest or brightly-colored sugar crystals. Boom! Done!

This recipe is fantastic!  I used it for this fun little pie palooza competition, and what do you know?  It won!  I made the graham cracker crust from scratch, and then when I put it in the oven, it actually took a little over 10 minutes for the bubbles to actually burst, but I'm glad I kept it in that long, because it kept it from getting all runny. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Search no further for a Key Lime pie recipe - I've been baking for years and used to make this pie using eggs for the custard.  I will never go that route again.  This is the perfect recipe.  I make my own crust with either graham crackers or vanilla wafer cookies.  Sometimes I put the grated lime zest in, sometimes I leave it out and to be honest, I do not notice any difference.  I use two cans of sweetened condensed milk and find I have to bake the pie for 30 minutes - it could be because I am using a glass pie pan.  I watch it at 5 minutes intervals.  This pie is delicious - very easy to make and is an absolute crowd pleaser.  One more thing...I use plain old limes - in my area there are no key limes.

This was a really big hit for my two dinner guest that my husband and I had last night. The only boo boo I made was I used regular limes instead of the itty bitty keylimes. :( But it still turned out wonderful. I used 2 cans fat free eagle brand (sweetened condensed milk) that was about 2 cups and MORE than enough. Even though it was a big hit, I feel I should of used 2 more limes. It was just perfect, but I think a can and half is more than enough. But I think the fact that I made the mistake of not using the keylimes might have something to do with it. But all in all, a great hit. Such a wonderful and easy recipe.  Next time, I will be using keylimes lol! xoxo happy eating people!

country:
None
text:
For how easy this was you can't beat it! I loved the creamy texture. I found that 2 cans of condensed milk is only 2 1/2 cups though, so to be safe I used enough from a 3rd can to make 3 cups. I know a lot of reviews said they just used 2 cans, but I wasn't sure. Also used bottle key lime juice and it was fine. I baked about 10 minutes and never saw bubbles. Better the next day. Edited: I've made this with 3 cups of sweetened evaporated milk and I've made it with 2 cans. I think it's much better made as written, the creamier taste and texture make this pie so much better.

So easy and so delicious.  I've never made key lime pie before, but with 1300+ reviews and such a high rating, I figured that I couldn't go wrong.

2 cans of condensed milk and the allotted amount of key lime juice gave this the perfect balance of sweet and tart.  It took me closer to 12 minutes to get it cooked to the proper consistency (I think that has more to do with my oven than the recipe itself).

The ONLY pie my boyfriend will eat is key lime, and he gave this 2 thumbs up.  It's definitely a keeper!

country:
None
text:
This was very good and well received by our guests. My only substitution was I made a home-made gluten free crust using 30 small gluten free gingersnaps and 5 TB butter (in food processor, pulse cookies into crumbs, mix with melted butter, press into pie plate, bake @ 350 for 7-8 min, let cool and use as recipe directs). I had bottled key lime juice as a back up to the actual key limes, in case what I bought wasn't enough...I ended up needing a couple tablespoons of it to equal 3/4. I would make this again. Thank you for an easy, tasty recipe :-)

userID:
6611203
Display Name:
ChefNET

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not a bad recipe, easy to do.  It could have had more lime taste to it, but my girlfriend said it was tangy enough.  Using actual limes is expensive; they are .99 cents each for me so I went with William-Sonoma's Key Lime juice.  Some recipes call for meringue but I've never seen that on a Key Lime pie, nor do I like it.  I made whipped cream (using heavy whipping cream, powedered sugar, vanilla and sour cream) and put a drop on top.  As others said, 2 cans of condensed milk is ABOUT 3 cups.  I could not find 9" pie crust, only 10", so it wasn't full to the top.  I would chill the pie for more then 2 hours; it was not ready by then.  I also used 1/2 cup of sour cream, however, it could probably be better with 1/4 cup.  All in all, its a work in progress.
Review:

text:
This was the first key lime pie I've ever made and I will never look for another recipe again. I made it for my friend's birthday and everyone who tasted it said it was the best they had ever had. It tastes very fresh because of the fresh lime juice and zest.

To more easily squeeze the key limes, I cut them into quarters and then squeezed them using my garlic press. I think it took about 15-20 key limes. I also baked it for about 9 minutes. 

You can't go wrong with this recipe, I promise!

text:
Unfortunately key limes aren't readily available in the UK so I made with regular limes but still came out great!  Graham crackers and graham cracker crusts aren't readily available here either so substituted 8 oz of digestive biscuits (crushed) combined with 3.5 oz butter (melted) to make the crust.  I followed the advice of others - 2 tins condensed milk = 3 cups and baked for no longer than 10 mins.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this pie on several occasions and it has been a hit. Very simple and easy to make. Don't do what I did the first time I made it; I measured out the Sweetened Condensed Milk and it took 3 cans to get 3 cups even though the can is 14 oz and there was too much and the pie wasn't tart enough. Now I go with the fact that 1 cup is 8 oz and 2 cans is 28 ounces (just 4 ounces over 3 cups) and the pie has been great. I like my pie a little tarter than most so I add a little extra key lime juice (not too much) and a little extra grated lime zest (again, not too much).

Everyone said it was great and I replied that it was easy, only 5 ingredients! text:
HUGE hit every time I make it. Around the 4th of July though, make sure you buy your key lime juice in advance--I checked seven stores that day and it was all sold out and I had to squeeze about 45 little key limes to get that much juice and it was BRUTAL. But its so worth it. I wouldn't really recommend mixing the zest inside--a guest once asked me if it was "grass" in the pie. Clueless, yes, but it made me realize that the green specks aren't too visibly appealing. Save the rind for some peel curls on top.

text:
A great,  easy and quick recipe for anyone to be able to put together.  After reading the other's reviews, I used my garlic crusher to squeeze the limes like suggested.  A tip to make it easier: zest your limes first then cut those up into quarter size pieces.  It makes them easier to squeeze out the juice and you get more out of each lime.  My pies also did not bubble, but I did not cook them over the recommended 5 to 8 minutes.  ENJOY!!!

Very good,  very creamy texture. I cheated and used bottled lime juice instead of squeezing the limes...limes were $0.65 EACH! There's no way I was making a pie for $20. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I love this recipe. This was the second key lime pie I made. The first one was from a different recipe on this site and used eggs, but this is now my favorite recipe. I made it for a party and it went really fast because it was soooo good. The only thing I did differently was make my own crust and that made it even better. I just added ground almonds and sugar to the graham cracker crumbs before adding melted butter, then baked it for a few minutes to make it a little crisp before adding the filling.  I think a great crust always enhances the pie eating experience.  This pie was just as good as the one I bought in Key West. Thanks for the recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving it 4 stars, though I'd rather give 4 1/2.  I made it largely as directed, however I had to zest using only a knife, so I couldn't exactly grate the zest.  It ended up in tiny confetti like squares of zest that I felt took away from the consistency of the pie.  Perhaps using a proper zester would have made it different, but I suspect I still would have had pieces of zest in it, just smaller pieces.  I really don't think it needed the zest though.  The bites I had that lacked the zest tasted great.  When I did get some of the zest, it did provide a burst of lime, but it seemed a bit inconsistent in taste with the pie.  I used a normal lime for the zest, and suspect that a key lime would have been better (we don't have key limes here).  Given my experience with and without zest, as long as you use true key lime juice, I suspect it would be an amazing pie even without the zest.  I've been to the Keys a few times, and I must say the supposedly "best" key lime pies I had down there, did not have noticeable pieces of zest in them.  They were perfectly smooth in consistency.

text:
I love Key Lime Pie and had been searching for a good recipe and I'm so happy I came across this one! It tastes wonderful, it takes a very short time to prepare, and a very short time to cook. Put it in the oven for ten minutes instead of 5-8 as the recipe suggests; it comes out better. Also, I used a bit more lime zest and it gave it that extra tart flavor and cut back on the sweetness of the sweetened condensed milk. If you, like me, prefer lip-puckering goodness, used the peel from two Mexican limes (about 5 key limes) and it'll do the trick!

text:
This recipe is super easy and quick--even if you make the graham cracker crust from scratch and freshly squeeze the limes. Five stars for speedy-fastness. Taste, on the other hand, was three star worthy. I thought this recipe was too sweet and rich with a heavy, creamy texture. I guess my preference leans towards a lighter, more refreshing key lime pie with a fluffier texture. Overall, not bad, but I won't be making this recipe again unless I need to put together a pie in half an hour or less.

Awsome!! I love the strong taste of lime.  Once I made it with lemons only and it was still really good. Do it with lemons if the flavor is too strong as it was for my sister-in-law or try half of the juice of limes and half of lemons if you don't like strong flavors.   Do use 2 cans of condensed milk.  It is a little less than what it asks for but it is just right for consistency and volume for one pie.  This is the first time my husband says he likes a dessert.  We loved it.   Thank you so much for the recipe because as a beginner it is very difficult to find something so amazing and so easy to make as this pie.

text:
Key Lime pie is my favorite and I'm a tough critic.  This recipe is absolutely THE BEST!  I live in Alaska, where Key limes are $3 apiece, so I used about half regular (squeezed) lime juice and the rest bottled (Nellie & Joe's Key West Lime Juice).  It worked very well.  The texture was firm and creamy and had that jaw tingling quality I look for in Key Lime pies.  I used the Graham Cracker Crust I recipe from this site and piped some homemade whipped cream on top.
Review:

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a Floridian and a fan of Key West I have to say I was skeptical.  However, based on great reviews I elected to make it for my girlfriend's birthday.  I am really glad I did.  Like most I used 2 cans of condensed milk, and in place of key limes I used the juice from eight (8) Persian limes and two (2) lemons.  Juicing your own citrus is quite the workout - be prepared.    Cooked for 15 minutes at 350, then I put in the fridge for 5 hours to cool.  The use of one tablespoon of zest seemed like a lot, but it made a big difference.    I will definitely be making this pie again - simple and amazing.  I would be interested in reducing the sugar and adding some mango nectar for a little variation...

I think it is better the next day because i am sitting here eating a piece for breakfast! Love it!

The PERFECT KEY LIME RECIPE! My family and I eat a lot of low-fat foods and are always trying recipes substituted with low/non-fat ingredients... some work and some don't. THIS ONE DID!! I had to make the pie crust with low-fat crackers then used the fat-free sweetened condensed milk and fat-free sour cream and the pie turned out so sweet and tart even my mom who doesn't like key lime pie asked me to make another one! If you love key lime pie you need to try this easy recipe!

text:
So simple to make, and so yummy! I was hesitant to try making a key lime pie, but there is no reason to fear this simple recipe. I couldn't really see the pinhole bubbles, but I just baked it for 10 minutes, and that seemed to work out just fine. I then froze it overnight, and the next morning spread some Cool Whip on top and sprinkled with some lime zest to make it nice and pretty. I put it in the fridge after that, and by the time we took it to our party that afternoon, it was perfect. Thanks for the awesome recipe!

text:
Not having tasted any florida pies was not sure how this was supposed to taste however it was so simple I used a vanilla wafer crust 1 and 1/2 cup crumbs with 6tbl butter wafer is already sweet so no sugar needed. The filling I mixed lime and lemon juice to get the keylime flavour since we don't have this type in my country. This was easy and soooo tasty right mix of sweet and tang and easy to make it took 10min in my oven.  Will make this again for sure.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you're like me, you look at this and think:  SOUR CREAM?!?  Don't be turned off by it.  I am the world's biggest Key Lime Pie snob, and this is hands down the best recipe I've found.  I tried many others that were much more complicated and not nearly as good.  Being the novice cook that I am, I didn't add the lime zest, but I can't imagine anything making this pie better.  Usually my cooking skills are limited to pushing START on the microwave, and any time I've tried zesting a lime(as other recipes insist on) I've ended up adding a bitter aftertaste.  Apparently I'm zesting too far down.  Other than that, I would say don't play with this recipe at all.  It doesn't need any tweaking.  Your friends will think you're some kind of genius in the kitchen with this pie and only you'll know how incredibly simple and easy it is.
Review:

text:
I had a craving for Key Lime Pie and decided to try this recipe. I made it exactly as directed (except I doubled it!) and squeezed about 40 key limes with a garlic press to get the juice. I coupled the recipe with a highly rated graham cracker crust recipe on allrecipes.com. Anyway, I gave one pie to a family friend who happens to be a professional chef. He immediately sent me an email after he tried the pie and said it was "hands down, the very best Key Lime Pie he had ever had in his entire life." My husband, who doesn't care for Key Lime Pie, also couldn't stop eating it. This is a winner. You won't regret trying this pie!

text:
This pie came out beautifully.  I had accidentally left the rack low in the oven when I placed the pies in so it took about 20 minutes or so before the tiny bubbles opened at the edges of the pie.  But after it cooled down and I refridgerated it the pie was nice and firm and maintained it's shape when cutting it, almost like cheesecake. I made this pie using reduced fat versions of the ingredients to cut the calories a bit.  Light sour cream, reduced fat sweetened condensed milk, reduced fat graham cracker pie crust. The only thing is that I thought the pie was just a tad too sweet for my taste.

userID:
1474033
Display Name:
ryann
isPro:

81

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1747.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The filling makes more than I expected. I bought a prepared crust--your basic shell--and had about 1 1/2 cups left over after the crust was filled completely. I recommend getting the crust that has the 2 extra servings. Also, 2 (14 oz) cans of sweetened condensed milk is not enough. It leaves you about 1/2 c. short. If you don't plan for this (which I didn't) you can use this substitute: combine over medium heat 3/4 c. evaporated milk & 3/4 c. sugar heat until dissolved. Use only what you need. The taste overall is a little sweeter than I like for a key lime pie but that might be due to the substitution. I also never got the bubbles to pop as stated in the recipe and ended up cooking it almost 15 minutes before I just took it out and am hoping for the best. ...
Review:

5

text:
Awesome recipe. I also used real key lime juice, only used 17 key limes though (i used a hand held lime juicer), 2 cans of low-fat sweetened condensed milk, and graham crackers pie crust from keebler. I didn't really see pin holes so I just took my pie out at 12 minutes, Place the plastic lid that came with the pie crust back on, and left it in the fridge overnight. Pie firmed up really well by morning. Thanks for the awesome recipe :)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I didn't have key limes, so used limes from the tree in the yard- it only took 3 limes to get enough juice! I used the "whipped cream" recipe from this site as well as the "graham cracker crust 1" recipe. The whipped cream was unnecessary- I actually scraped it off. And I wouldn't use the cinnamon in the crust next time when paired with this pie. I also want to try with key limes, because my limes were super sweet, and it would be nice to have a bit more tang with this pie. Still, I was amazed at how easy this was to make. Everyone raved about this pie ("scrumptious!", "heavenly", "soooooooooo delicious!" were some of the comments).  This would be great to whip up for potlucks- it looks pretty, tastes yummy, and is easy to make. Thanks! PS: The pie seems to improve a fair bit after being refrigerated overnight.

Got lots of compliments and people think you took effort in making a homemade pie from scratch, when it takes close to no time to make.  Fantastic!!

text:
Pretty good recipe!  I would give this a 5, but the recipe needed some tweaking.  First, 3/4 c. of lime juice was WAY overpowering.  Also, 3 cups of sweetened condensed milk about made the pie pan overflow - 2 cups is the perfect amount.  Overall, a very easy and tasty recipe (once you decrease the lime juice)!

country:
None
text:
Excellent -so fast & easy!  I used 2 (14oz) cans of fat-free sweetened condensed milk (which is still incredibly high in calories), fat-free sour cream, Nellie & Joe's Key West Lime Juice and just a pinch of lime zest.  I made a crust out of some shortbread cookies and a little butter only because I was out of graham crackers.  It took 16 minutes in the oven before I saw the "tiny bubbles" on the surface of the pie that the recipe refers to but the pie didn't brown and it was the perfect texture.  This is extremely rich but I like it because it means that a little goes a long way!

text:
Fabulous pie!  This is really pretty quick and simple to make.  I added a few drops of green food coloring and because I had a frozen pie crust I had made a few weeks earlier, I baked the pie crust and after it cooled, added the key lime mixture.  It was so good, it didn't even need whipped topping, but was excellent with a dollop. I also used Mexican limes which were available at the grocery store and are a little larger than key limes.  They were very juicy and was quicker to get the 3/4 cup of lime juice. I couldn't tell the difference in taste.

text:
This was my first stab at key lime pie but my boyfriend is a connoisseur so I was nervous to make this recipe, (especially because this was the only one that didn't call for eggs).  I used regular limes instead of key limes and it worked just fine.  My bf said it's the best key lime he has ever tasted (and he should know, he used to live in Florida).  I will definitely make this recipe again. One more thing; there was way more filling than could fit into one, 9 inch pic crust.  I got mini pie crusts and made mini pies with the rest.

text:
Excellent, excellent - only made a few modifications. Used 1 1/2 cans of sweetened condensed milk and used 2/3 cup of frozen limeade concentrate thawed (my secret ingredient) and also bumped up the zest of limes to two. 

Had to cook for about 18 minutes and let it cool 1/2 hr and then placed in the fridge. I never knew key lime pie was so easy to make!

text:
Really easy and really tasty.  I used home made crust which put the pie over the top!  I used 2/3 cup of the "double strength" concentrate and zest from 2 regular limes. 2 cans of condensed milk was perfect for an 8" pie.  I baked it 8 minutes (as others suggested), saw the tiny bubbles and took it right out.  Perfect! I look forward to another reason to make this pie--I loved "sampling" the filling as I tweaked the flavor. Thanks for the recipe!

Key lime pie has been a long time favorite of mine and this recipe is the easiest and tastiest key lime pie I've ever made! I followed the directions to the letter....I made six individual mini pies and had a lot left over but no more graham cracker crust so I made a crust out of vanilla wafers (20 wafers + 3 tbsp butter + 2 tbsp brown sugar). This one turned out even better than the mini pies.

None
text:
Fear the Key Lime Pie no more with this recipe! I needed to make 100 slices of Key Lime Pie for a luncheon theater & I am so pleased that I chose this recipe! The pies set up beautifully, tasted delicious, and were very easy to prepare. Because of the volume of desserts I needed to serve, I did use a prepared graham cracker crust- But I used an extra large one ( 2 extra servings/each crust)and the quantity of pie filling was just right for the over sized crust. We topped each slice with whipped cream and sprinkled lime zest over that for a sassy service. It was so good, I made one for my own Memorial Day picnic at home!

text:
A dessert this good should not be so easy to make. I used 2 cans of condensed milk and because I didn't have access to key limes, used half lime and half lemon juice as another reviewer suggested. I live in Ireland, so I made a crust from digestive biscuits rather than graham crackers. I chose the recipe because it looked simple and I could make it ahead, but my guests couldn't have been more appreciative if I'd slaved over it for hours. Nice creamy texture.

The only Key Lime Pie recipe I will ever use again!  Everything about this pie was great!  Easy to put together, quick to bake, tastes delicious, wonderful texture.
